chunks.original_text: 又方，盐豉及羊尿一升，捣，令熟，以渍之。 又方，细锉黄檗五斤，以水三斗，煮，渍之。 亦治攻阴肿痛。 又方，作坎令深三赤，少容两足，烧坎令热，以酒灌坎中，着屐踞坎中，壅勿令泄。 又方，煮羊桃汁渍之，杂少盐豉尤好。 又方，煮马矢若羊矢汁，渍。 又方，猪膏和羊矢涂之，亦佳。 又方，以牛肉裹肿处，肿消痛止。 又方，捣常思草，绞取汁，以渍足。 又方，猪蹄一具，合葱煮，去滓，内少盐，以渍之。 毒病下部生疮者，烧盥以深导之，不过三。 又方，生漆涂之，绵导之。 又方，大丸艾灸下部，此谓穷无药。 又方，取蚓三升，以水五升，得二升半，尽服之。 又方，煮桃皮，煎如饴，以绵合导之。 又方，水中荇菜，捣，绵裹导之，日五易，差。 ， 又方，榉皮、槲皮合煮汁如枯糖以导之。 又，浓煮桃皮饮之，最良。 又方，捣蛇莓汁，服三合，日三，水渍乌梅令浓，并内崖蜜，数数饮。 若病人齿无色，舌上白，或喜睡眠，愦愦不知痛痒处，或下痢，急治下部。 不晓此者，但攻其上，不以下为意，下部生虫，虫食其肛，肛烂见五脏便死。 治之方： 取鸡子白，内漆合搅，还内壳中，仰头吞之，当吐虫，则愈。 又方，烧马蹄作灰，细末，猪脂和，涂绵以导下部，日数度，差。 又方，桃人十五枚，苦酒二升，盐一合，煮取六合，服之。 又方，烧艾於管中熏之，令烟入下部，中少雄黄杂妙，此方是溪温，故尔兼取彼治法。 又有病□下不止者，乌头二两，女萎、云实各一两，桂二分，蜜丸如桐子，水服五丸，一日三服。 治下部卒痛如鸟啄之方，赤小豆、大#7豆各一升，合捣，两囊贮，蒸之令熟，更互坐，即愈。 此本在杂治中，亦是伤寒毒气所攻。 故凡治伤寒方甚多，其有诸麻黄、葛根、桂枝、柴胡、青龙、白虎、四顺、四逆二十余方，并是至要者，而药难尽备，且诊候须明悉，别所在撰大方中，今唯载前四方，尤是急须者耳。 其黄膏赤散，在辟病条中，预合，初觉患便服之。 伤寒、时行、温疫，三名同一种耳，而源本小异。 其冬月伤於寒，或疾行力作汗出得风玲，至夏发，名为伤寒。 其冬月不甚寒，多暖气及西风，使人骨节缓惰受病，至春发，名为时行。 其年岁中有疠气兼挟鬼毒相注，名为温病。 如此诊候相似，又贵胜雅言，总名伤寒，世俗因号为时行，道术符刻，言五温亦复殊，大归终止，是共途也。 然自有阳明、少阳、阴毒、阳毒为异耳。 少阴病例不发热，而腹满下痢，最难治也。 附方 《必效方》：治天行一二日者，麻黄一大两，去节，以水四升，煮，去沫，取二升，去滓，着米一匙及豉，为稀粥，取强一升，先作熟汤，浴淋头百余碗，然后服粥，厚覆取汗，於夜最佳。
chunks.translated_text:
Another remedy: Pound one *sheng* each of salted *chi* and sheep urine until well-mixed, then soak the affected area.

Another remedy: Finely chop five *jin* of *huangbo*, boil in three *dou* of water, and soak the affected area. This also treats swelling and pain in the private parts.

Another remedy: Dig a pit three *chi* deep, just large enough to hold both feet. Heat the pit thoroughly, then pour wine into it. Step into the pit wearing clogs, ensuring the steam is contained and does not escape.

Another remedy: Boil *yangtao* juice and soak the affected area; adding a small amount of salted *chi* is especially effective.

Another remedy: Boil horse dung or sheep dung in water and soak the affected area.

Another remedy: Mix sheep dung with lard and apply to the swelling; this is also effective.

Another remedy: Wrap the swollen area with beef, and the swelling will subside and pain cease.

Another remedy: Pound *changsicao*, extract the juice, and soak the feet in it.

Another remedy: Boil one pig’s trotter with scallions, remove the dregs, add a small amount of salt, and soak the affected area.

For toxic disease causing sores in the lower body, burn a *guan* vessel and insert the ashes deeply as a suppository; no more than three applications are needed.

Another remedy: Apply raw lacquer and insert it with cotton.

Another remedy: Form large moxa cones and apply moxibustion to the lower body—this is a last resort when no other medicine is available.

Another remedy: Take three *sheng* of earthworms, boil in five *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain, and consume the entire decoction.

Another remedy: Boil peach bark until it reduces to a syrup-like consistency, then combine with cotton for insertion.

Another remedy: Pound water *xingcai*, wrap in cotton, and insert; replace five times daily until cured.

Another remedy: Boil *ju* bark and *hu* bark together until the liquid thickens like malt sugar, then use for insertion.

Another: A thick decoction of boiled peach bark, taken as a drink, is most effective.

Another remedy: Pound *shemei* to extract the juice, take three *ge* three times daily. Soak black plums in water until concentrated, then add honey from cliff bees, and drink frequently.

If the patient’s teeth lose their color, the tongue turns white, or they become excessively drowsy, confused, and insensitive to pain, or if they suffer from diarrhea, urgently treat the lower body. Those who do not recognize this will only address the upper body, neglecting the lower, allowing worms to grow in the lower body. These worms will consume the anus, and when the anus rots to reveal the five viscera, death follows.

Remedy: Take egg white, mix with lacquer, return it to the eggshell, and swallow it while facing upward. This will induce vomiting of the worms, leading to recovery.

Another remedy: Burn horse hooves to ash, grind finely, mix with lard, and apply to cotton for insertion into the lower body several times daily until cured.

Another remedy: Boil fifteen peach kernels, two *sheng* of bitter wine, and one *ge* of salt until six *ge* remain, then consume.

Another remedy: Burn mugwort in a tube to fumigate the lower body, allowing the smoke to enter. Mix a small amount of realgar into the mugwort—this method is used for *xiwen* (stream warmth), hence the inclusion of its treatment.

For incessant diarrhea from an unknown cause: Two *liang* of *wutou*, one *liang* each of *nüwei* and *yunshi*, and two *fen* of *gui*. Form into honey pills the size of *tongzi* seeds, and take five pills with water three times daily.

For sudden pain in the lower body resembling a bird’s pecking: Pound one *sheng* each of red adzuki beans and large beans, place in two pouches, steam until hot, and alternate sitting on them to cure. This was originally recorded in the miscellaneous treatments section and is also caused by toxic *qi* from cold damage.

Thus, while there are many remedies for cold damage—including those using *mahuang*, *gegen*, *guizhi*, *chaihu*, *qinglong*, *baihu*, *sishun*, and *sini*, totaling over twenty essential formulas—the ingredients are difficult to fully prepare. Moreover, diagnosis must be precise, and other comprehensive formulas are recorded elsewhere. Here, only the four most urgently needed formulas are included. The *huanggao* and *chisang* remedies are found in the disease-prevention section and should be prepared in advance; take them at the first sign of illness.

Cold damage (*shanghan*), seasonal epidemics (*shixing*), and warm epidemics (*wenyi*) are three names for the same category of illness, though their origins differ slightly. When one is harmed by cold in winter, or when sweating from strenuous activity exposes one to wind and cold, the illness manifests in summer—this is called *shanghan*. When winter is not very cold, and warm air or westerly winds cause the joints to relax and become susceptible, the illness manifests in spring—this is called *shixing*. When pestilential *qi* and demonic toxins afflict a person in a given year, it is called *wenbing*. Though the diagnostic signs are similar, and refined discourse prefers the general term *shanghan*, common people call it *shixing*. Daoist talismans and inscriptions also distinguish the *five warm* diseases, but ultimately, they share the same path. However, there are differences such as *yangming*, *shaoyang*, *yin* toxin, and *yang* toxin. Cases of *shaoyin* disease that do not involve fever but present with abdominal fullness and diarrhea are the most difficult to treat.

**Attached Formula**
From *The Infallible Remedies*: For seasonal epidemic illness of one or two days’ duration: Take one large *liang* of *mahuang* (remove the nodes), boil in four *sheng* of water, skim off the foam, and reduce to two *sheng*. Remove the dregs, add a spoonful of rice and *chi* to make a thin porridge, and consume one *sheng* while strong. First, prepare hot water and pour over one hundred bowls’ worth over the head, then consume the porridge. Cover thickly to induce sweating; doing this at night is most effective.

Another formula for seasonal epidemic with vexing thirst: Take one medium cup of fresh lotus root juice, blend with one *ge* of raw honey, divide into two doses, and consume.

**Formulas from *Victorious Golden Remedies***
For seasonal epidemic *heat disease* with delirious speech and heart vexation: Take *kushen* in any quantity, stir-fry until yellow, and grind to powder. For each dose, take two *qian*, decoct in one cup of water to eight parts, and consume warm. Repeat for three doses—recovery follows whether sweating occurs or not.

**Formulas from *Extensive Relief Remedies***
For *cold damage* of both *yin* and *yang* toxins, *Black Dragon Elixir*: Take one *liang* of imported *liuhuang*, pound with a willow mallet for three days; take one *liang* of *badou* (count the shells), and two *sheng* of a wok. First place the *liuhuang* to cover the wok’s base, then add the *badou*, and cover with more *liuhuang*. Pour in half a *sheng* of strong vinegar, seal tightly with a lid, and further seal the edges with wet paper to prevent steam escape. When the paper dries, remoisten with vinegar. Add a small amount of rice vinegar and steamed cake, pound again until cool enough to form pills the size of a *chicken’s head*.

For *yang* toxin, decoct forty-nine *chi* grains and two stalks of *cong bai* in one cup of water, and swallow one pill without chewing.

**Formulas from *Sun Yonghe’s Remedies***
For *yang* toxin entering the stomach with frequent bloody stool and unbearable pain: Take five large *yujin* roots and one *zaojiazi*-sized *niuhuang*, grind separately, then combine as a powder. For each dose, decoct in one cup of vinegar *jiang* water to three boils, and consume warm.

**Formulas from *Sun Zhao’s Oral Instructions***
For *yin* toxin *cold damage* with reversal cold of the limbs, deep and faint pulse, headache, and lumbar heaviness, also treating *yin* toxin, *ke ni* (hiccup-reversal), and similar conditions: Take equal parts *chuan wutou* and *ganjiang*, grind coarsely, stir-fry until discolored, cool, then grind finely. For each *qian*, decoct in one cup of water with a pinch of salt to half a cup, and consume warm.

Another formula for *yin* excess obstructing *yang* in *cold damage*, where the patient is vexingly hot yet unwilling to drink water: *Thunderbolt Powder* is appropriate. **Formulas from *Sagely Benevolence Remedies***

For seasonal epidemic with jaundice, frenzied heart vexation, and delirium: Take one large yellow *gualou*, soak in nine *ge* of freshly drawn water; strain the juice, add half a large *ge* of honey and eight *fen* of *poxiao*, stir until dissolved, and divide into two doses—recovery follows.

**Formulas from *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library***
For seasonal epidemic of four or five days’ duration with *jiexiong* (chest bind), fullness, pain, and high fever: Take one *liang* of *kushen*, slice, decoct in two *sheng* of vinegar to one *sheng* and two *ge*, and consume entirely—recovery follows vomiting. Another formula: Take one chicken egg, boil for three to five boils, remove and soak in water until the exterior is cooked but the interior remains warm, then swallow—effective.

**Formulas from *Sagely Benevolence Remedies***
For seasonal epidemic with *ou ni* (vomiting-reversal) and inability to retain food: Take half a *liang* of *banxia*, soak and wash seven times in hot water to remove sliminess, and one *liang* of fresh ginger; chop together, decoct in one large cup of water to six parts, remove dregs, divide into two doses, and consume warm at any time.

**Formulas from *Master Shen’s Remedies***
For incessant *wa* (belching) in *cold damage*: Wash *banxia* thoroughly, dry, grind to powder, and take one *qianbi* with fresh ginger decoction.

For unremitting cough and hiccup in *cold damage*, and persistent *yue ni* (hiccup-reversal): Take one *liang* of *xiang* and one *liang* of dried *shi di*, bake dry, grind to powder, and take one *qian* with ginseng decoction at any time.

Dragon bone, half a *jin*, crush and boil in one *dou* of water to yield four *sheng*; submerge in a well to chill. Take five *ge* at a time, gradually increasing the dose, and drink freely—especially suitable for the elderly and children.

Another formula: Grind four *liang* of dried ginger into powder, mix with hot water, and ingest at once. Cover warmly to induce sweating, and cease once relief is obtained.

When two men or two women engage in intercourse, they do not transmit *yin exchange* to one another; thus, the term *exchange* refers to the interchange of yin and yang.

To prevent relapse in a convalescent patient, take twenty fingernail clippings from a woman’s hands and feet, along with a one-*chi* length of the lower hem of her undergarment. Burn to ash and ingest with wine or rice broth.

Grind ten parts oyster shell and five parts gypsum into powder and ingest one *square-inch spoonful* with wine three or four times daily. Another formula: Grind two *liang* each of licorice and gypsum into powder. Ingest one *square-inch spoonful* with fermented rice water twice daily to resolve the condition.

Take one *liang* each of hemp seeds, cypress seeds, dried ginger, and asarum, along with half a *liang* of prepared aconite. Grind into powder, and at dawn, have each household member ingest one *square-inch spoonful* with well water. In severe epidemics, take three doses daily.

For those ill for four or five days, boil one *spoonful* in three *sheng* of water, ingest one *sheng*, and cover to induce sweating.

Grind equal parts realgar, cinnabar, croton seeds, alum, aconite, and dried ginger into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of sesame seeds. At dawn, face the sun and swallow one pill daily for nine days to remain disease-free.

chunks.original_text: 治疟病方，鼠妇、豆豉二七枚，合捣，令相和，未发时服二丸，欲发时服一丸。 又方，青蒿一握，以水二升渍，绞取汁，尽服之。 又方，用独父蒜，於白炭上烧之，末，服方寸匕。 又方，五月五日，蒜一片去皮，中破之，刀割，合容巴豆一枚，去心皮，内蒜中令合，以竹挟以火炙之，取可热，捣为三丸，未发前服一丸，不止，复与一丸。 又方，取蜘蛛一枚，芦管中密塞，管中以绾颈，过发时，乃解去也。 又方，日始出时，东向日再拜，毕，正长跪，向日叉手，当闭气，以书墨注其管两耳中，各七注，又丹书舌上，言子日死，毕，复再拜，还去勿顾，安卧勿食，过发时断，即差。 又方，多煮豉汤，饮数升，令得大吐，便差。 又方，取蜘蛛一枚，着饭中，合丸吞之。 又方，临发时，捣大附子下筛，以苦酒和之，涂背上。 又方，鼠妇虫子四枚，各一以饴糖裹之，丸服便断，即差。 又方，常山，捣下筛成末，三两，真丹一两，白蜜和，捣百杵，丸如梧子，先发服三丸，中服三丸，临卧服三丸，无不断者，常用效。 又方，大开口，度上下唇，以绳度心头，灸此度下头百壮，又灸脊中央五十壮，过发时，灸二十壮。 又方，破一大豆去皮，书一片作日字，一片作月字，左手持日，右手持月，吞之立愈，向日服之，勿令人知也。 又方，皂荚三两，去皮炙，巴豆一两，去心皮，捣，丸如大豆大，一服一枚。 又方，巴豆一枚，去心皮，射菵如巴豆大，枣一枚，去皮，合捣成丸，先发各服一丸，如梧子大也。 又方，常山、知母、甘草、麻黄等分，捣，蜜和丸如大豆，服三丸，比发时令过毕。 又方，常山三两，甘草半两，水酒各半升，合煮取半升，先发时一服，比发令三服尽。 又方，常山三两，到，以酒三升，渍二三日，平旦作三合服，欲呕之，临发又服二合，便断。 旧酒亦佳，急亦可煮。 又方，常山三两，秫米三百粒，以水六升，煮取三升，分之服，至发时令尽。 又方，若发作无常，心下烦热，取常山二两，甘草一两半，合以水六升，取二升，分再服，当快吐，仍断，勿饮食。 老疟久不断者，常山三两，鳖甲一两，炙，升麻一两，附子一两，乌贼骨一两，以酒六升渍#1之，小令近火，一宿成，服一合，比发可数作。 又方，华芦、皂荚各一两，炙，巴豆二十五枚，并捣，熬令黄，依法捣，蜜丸如小豆，空心服一丸，未发时一丸，临发时又一丸，勿饮食。 又方，牛膝茎叶一把，切，以酒三升服，令微有酒气。 不即断，更作，不过三服而止。 又方，末龙骨方寸匕，先发一时，以酒一升半，煮三沸，及热尽服，温覆取汗，便即效。 又方，常山三两，甘草半两，知母一两，捣，蜜丸，至先发时，服如梧子大十丸，次服减七丸八丸，后五六丸，即差。 又方，先发二时，以炭火床下，令脊脚极暖被覆，过时乃止，此治先寒后热者。 又方，先炙鳖甲，捣末方寸匕，至时令三服尽，用火炙，无不断。 又方，常山三两，捣筛，鸡子白和之丸，空腹三十丸，去发食久三十丸，发时三十丸，或吐或否也，从服药至过发时，勿饮食。 治温疟不下食，知母、鳖甲炙、常山各二两，地骨皮三两切，竹叶一升切，石膏四两，以水七升，煮二升五合，分温三服。

**Remedies for Malarial Diseases (Section Sixteen)**

For malarial disease: Take fourteen *shimu* (pill bugs) and fourteen fermented soybeans, pound together, and blend. Take two pills when the episode has not yet begun, and one pill when it is about to strike.

Another remedy: Take a handful of sweet wormwood, steep in two *sheng* of water, wring out the juice, and consume it all.

Another remedy: Burn a single clove of *dufu* garlic over white charcoal, grind into powder, and take one *square-inch spoonful*.

Another remedy: On the fifth day of the fifth month, take a slice of garlic, peel and split it open, then carve with a knife to hold one *badou* (croton seed). Remove the heart and skin of the *badou*, place it inside the garlic, secure with bamboo, and roast over fire until hot. Pound into three pills. Take one pill before the episode begins; if it does not cease, take another.

Another remedy: Take one spider, seal it tightly in a reed tube, and tie the tube around the neck. Remove it only after the episode has passed.

Another remedy: At sunrise, face east and bow twice. Then kneel upright, clasp hands toward the sun, and hold your breath. Use ink to mark each ear seven times, then write with cinnabar on the tongue, saying, “Die on the *zi* day.” Bow twice again, leave without looking back, lie down calmly, and refrain from eating. The episode will cease after its time has passed.

Another remedy: Boil a large amount of fermented soybean broth, drink several *sheng* to induce heavy vomiting, and the disease will be cured.

Another remedy: Place one spider in cooked rice, form into a pill, and swallow it.

Another remedy: When the episode is about to begin, pound large *fuzi* (aconite) into powder, mix with bitter wine, and apply to the back.

Another remedy: Take four *shimu* larvae, wrap each in malt sugar, and swallow as pills to immediately cease the episode.

Another remedy: Pound three *liang* of *changshan* (dichroa root) into fine powder, mix with one *liang* of *zhen dan* (cinnabar) and white honey, and pound one hundred times to form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take three pills before the episode, three at mid-episode, and three before sleep. There is no case where this does not cease the disease; it is consistently effective.

Another remedy: Open the mouth wide, measure the upper and lower lips with a string, then measure from the string to the heart. Moxa one hundred *zhuang* at this measured point below, and moxa fifty *zhuang* at the center of the spine. After the episode has passed, moxa twenty *zhuang*.

Another remedy: Split a large soybean, remove the skin, and inscribe one half with the character for “sun” and the other with “moon.” Hold the “sun” in the left hand and the “moon” in the right, swallow them facing the sun, and do not let others know.

Another remedy: Take three *liang* of *zaojia* (Chinese honey locust), remove the skin and roast, add one *liang* of *badou*, remove the heart and skin, pound together, and form pills the size of large soybeans. Take one pill per dose.

Another remedy: Take one *badou*, remove the heart and skin, and one piece of *shegong* (arrowhead) the size of a *badou*, along with one jujube (peeled). Pound together into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take one pill at the onset of each episode.

Another remedy: Take equal parts *changshan*, *zhimu* (anemarrhena), *gancao* (licorice), and *mahuang* (ephedra), pound into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of large soybeans. Take three pills before the episode to ensure it passes completely.

Another remedy: Take three *liang* of *changshan* and half a *liang* of *gancao*, boil in half a *sheng* each of water and wine, and reduce to half a *sheng*. Take one dose before the episode begins, and finish three doses by the time the episode strikes.

Another remedy: Steep three *liang* of *changshan* in three *sheng* of wine for two or three days. At dawn, take three *ge* (a measure), and induce vomiting. Take another two *ge* at the onset of the episode, and it will cease. Aged wine is also effective; in urgent cases, it may be boiled.

Another remedy: Take three *liang* of *changshan* and three hundred grains of *shu* millet, boil in six *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide and consume before the episode begins.

Another remedy: If the episodes occur irregularly with heat and vexation in the heart, take two *liang* of *changshan* and one and a half *liang* of *gancao*, boil in six *sheng* of water, and reduce to two *sheng*. Divide into two doses and consume to induce rapid vomiting, then cease. Do not eat or drink.

For chronic malaria that does not cease: Take three *liang* of *changshan*, one *liang* of roasted *biejia* (turtle shell), one *liang* of *shengma* (cimicifuga), one *liang* of *fuzi*, and one *liang* of *wuzeigu* (cuttlefish bone). Steep in six *sheng* of wine near a small fire overnight. Take one *ge* per dose, and take several doses before the episode strikes.

Another remedy: Take one *liang* each of *hualu* (flowering reed) and *zaojia*, roast, and add twenty-five *badou*. Pound together, stir-fry until yellow, and follow the method to pound into pills the size of small soybeans with honey. Take one pill on an empty stomach, one before the episode, and one at the onset. Do not eat or drink.

Another remedy: Take a handful of *niuxi* (achyranthes) stems and leaves, chop, and steep in three *sheng* of wine. Consume until there is a slight wine scent. If the disease does not cease, repeat the process, but do not exceed three doses.

Another remedy: Grind one *square-inch spoonful* of *longgu* (dragon bone) into powder. One hour before the episode, boil in one and a half *sheng* of wine for three boils, then consume while hot. Cover to induce sweating, and it will be effective immediately.

Another remedy: Take three *liang* of *changshan*, half a *liang* of *gancao*, and one *liang* of *zhimu*, pound into powder, and form pills with honey. At the onset of the episode, take ten pills the size of *wutong* seeds. For subsequent doses, reduce to seven or eight pills, then five or six pills, and the disease will be cured.

Another remedy: Two hours before the episode, place a charcoal fire under the bed to warm the spine and feet thoroughly. Cover with blankets, and cease after the episode has passed. This treats cases where cold precedes heat.

Another remedy: Roast *biejia* in advance, pound into powder, and take one *square-inch spoonful* in three doses at the onset of the episode. Moxa with fire, and there is no case where the disease does not cease.

Another remedy: Take three *liang* of *changshan*, pound into powder, and mix with egg white to form pills. Take thirty pills on an empty stomach, thirty pills long after eating, and thirty pills at the onset of the episode. Whether vomiting occurs or not, do not eat or drink from the time of taking the medicine until after the episode has passed.

For warm malaria with loss of appetite: Take two *liang* each of *zhimu*, roasted *biejia*, and *changshan*, three *liang* of *digupi* (wolfberry root bark), one *sheng* of chopped bamboo leaves, and four *liang* of *shigao* (gypsum). Boil in seven *sheng* of water and reduce to two *sheng* and five *ge*. Divide into three warm doses.

chunks.original_text: 忌蒜、热面、猪、鱼。 治瘴疟，常山、黄连、豉熬各三两，附子二两，炮，捣筛，蜜丸，空腹服四丸，欲发三丸，饮下之，服药后至过发时，勿吃食。 若兼诸痢者，黄连、犀角各三两，牡蛎、香豉各二两，并熬，龙骨四两，捣筛，蜜丸，服四十丸，日再服，饮下。 无时节发者，常山二两，甘草一两半，豉五合，绵裹，以水六升，煮取三升，再服，快吐。 无问年月，可治三十年者，常山、黄连各三两，酒一斗，宿渍之，晓以瓦釜煮取六升，一服八合，比发时令得三服，热当吐，冷当利，服之无不差者，半料合服得。 劳疟积久，众治不差者，生长大牛膝一大虎口，以水六升，煮取二升，空腹一服，欲发一服。 禳一切疟，是日抱雄鸡，一时令作大声，无不差。 又方，未发头向南卧，五心及额舌七处，闭气书鬼字。 咒法，发日执一石於水滨，一气咒云：眢眢圆圆，行路非难，捉取疟鬼，送与河官，急急如律令。 投於水，不得回顾。 治一切疟，乌梅丸方。 甘草二两，乌梅肉熬、人参、桂心、肉从蓉、知母、牡丹各二两，常山、升麻、桃人去皮尖熬，乌豆皮熬膜取皮各三两，桃人研，欲丸入之，捣筛，蜜丸，苏屠臼捣一万杵，发日五更酒下三十丸，平旦四十丸，欲发四十丸，不发日空腹四十丸，晚三十丸，无不差，徐服。 后十余日，吃肥肉发之也。 □见疟，白驴蹄二分，熬，大黄四分，绿豆三分，末，砒霜二分，光明砂半分，雄黄一分，捣，蜜丸如梧子，发日平旦冷水服二丸，七日内忌油。 附方 《外台秘要》：治疟不痊，乾姜、高良姜等分，为末，每服一钱，水一中盏，煎至七分服。 《圣惠方》：治久患疟劳瘴等方，用鳖甲三两，涂酥，炙令黄，去裙为末，临发时温酒调下二钱匕。 治疟，用桃人一百个，去皮尖，於乳钵中细研成膏，不得犯生水，候成膏，入黄丹三钱，丸如梧子大，每服三丸，当发日，面北用温酒吞下，如不饮酒，井花水亦得。 五月五日午时合，忌鸡犬妇人见。 又方，用小蒜，不拘多少，研极烂，和黄丹少许，以聚为度，丸如鸡头大，候乾，每服一丸，新汲水下，面东服，至妙。 治卒发癫狂病方第十七 治卒癫疾方，灸阴茎上宛宛中三壮，得小便通则愈。 又方，灸阴茎上三壮，囊下缝二七壮。 又方，灸两乳头三壮，又灸足大指本聚毛中七壮，灸足小指本节七壮。 又方，取葶苈一升，捣三千杵，取白犬倒悬之，以杖犬，令血出，承取以和葶苈末，服如麻子大一丸，三服取差。 又方，莨菪子三升，酒五升渍之，出曝乾，渍尽酒止，捣，服一钱匕，日三，勿多，益狂。 又《小品》癫狂莨菪散　莨菪子三升，末之，酒一升，渍多日出，捣之，以向汁和，绞去滓，汤上煎，令可丸，服如小豆三丸，日三，口面当觉急，头中有虫行者，额及手足应有赤色处，如此必是差候。 若未见，服取尽矣。 又方，末房葵，温酒服一刀圭至二三，身润又小不仁为候。 又方，自缢死者绳，烧三指撮，服之。 凡癫疾，发则仆地，吐涎沫，无知强掠起如狂，反遗粪者，难治。 治卒发狂方，烧虾蟆，捣末，服方寸匕，日三服之，酒服。 又方，卧其人着地，以冷水淋其面，为终日淋之。 治卒狂言鬼语方，针其足大拇指爪甲下入少许，即止。

Avoid garlic, hot noodles, pork, and fish.

For miasmic malaria: Take three *liang* each of *changshan*, *huanglian* (coptis), and roasted *chi* (fermented soybeans), two *liang* of *fuzi* (aconite, blast-fried). Pound into powder, form honey pills, and take four pills on an empty stomach, three pills at the onset of the episode, swallowing with water. Do not eat from the time of taking the medicine until after the episode has passed.

If accompanied by various dysenteries: Take three *liang* each of *huanglian* and *xijiao* (rhinoceros horn), two *liang* each of *muli* (oyster shell) and roasted *xiangchi* (fermented soybeans), and four *liang* of *longgu* (dragon bone). Pound into powder, form honey pills, and take forty pills twice daily, swallowing with water.

For malaria with no fixed onset: Take two *liang* of *changshan*, one and a half *liang* of *gancao* (licorice), and five *ge* of *chi* (fermented soybeans). Wrap in silk, boil in six *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Take in two doses to induce prompt vomiting.

For malaria of any duration, even up to thirty years: Take three *liang* each of *changshan* and *huanglian*, steep in one *dou* of wine overnight, then boil in an earthenware pot in the morning to reduce to six *sheng*. Take eight *ge* per dose, ensuring three doses before the onset of the episode. If hot, vomiting will occur; if cold, diarrhea will follow. No case will fail to be cured. Half the formula suffices.

For chronic labor malaria unresponsive to various treatments: Take a large handful of fresh *niuxi* (achyranthes), boil in six *sheng* of water, and reduce to two *sheng*. Take one dose on an empty stomach and another at the onset of the episode.

To ward off all malaria: On the day of onset, hold a rooster and make it crow loudly at the same time—no case will fail to be cured.

Another remedy: Before the onset, lie facing south. At the five centers (palms, soles, and crown) and the forehead and tongue—seven places in total—hold the breath and write the character for "ghost."

Incantation method: On the day of onset, hold a stone by the water’s edge and chant in one breath: *"Yuanyuan yuanyuan, xinglu fei nan, zhuoqu nuegui, song yu heguan. Jiji ru lüling."* Cast the stone into the water without looking back.

For all malaria, the *Wumei* (mume) pill formula: Two *liang* of *gancao*, two *liang* each of roasted *wumei* (mume) flesh, *renshen* (ginseng), *guixin* (cinnamon bark), *roucongrong* (cistanche), *zhimu*, and *mudan* (moutan), three *liang* each of *changshan*, *shengma* (cimicifuga), roasted *taoren* (peach kernel, peeled and pitted), and roasted *wudoupi* (black soybean skin). Grind the *taoren* separately and add when forming pills. Pound with a mortar and pestle ten thousand times, form honey pills, and take thirty pills with wine at dawn on the day of onset, forty pills at daybreak, forty pills at the onset, forty pills on an empty stomach on non-onset days, and thirty pills in the evening. No case will fail to be cured. Take slowly. After ten days, eat fatty meat to induce a recurrence.

For visible malaria: Take two parts roasted *bailvti* (white donkey hoof), four parts *dahuang* (rhubarb), three parts *lüdou* (mung beans), two parts *pishuang* (arsenic trioxide), half a part *guangmingsha* (cinnabar), and one part *xionghuang* (realgar). Pound into powder, form honey pills the size of *wutou* seeds, and take two pills with cold water at daybreak on the day of onset. Avoid oil for seven days.

**Additional Formulas**
From *Waitai Miyao*: For unrelenting malaria, take equal parts *ganjiang* (dried ginger) and *gaoliangjiang* (galangal), grind into powder, and take one *qian* per dose, boiled in one *zhongzhan* of water until reduced to seven parts.

From *Shenghui Fang*: For chronic malaria, consumptive malaria, and miasmic malaria, take three *liang* of *biejia* (turtle shell), coat with suet, roast until yellow, remove the rim, and grind into powder. Take two *qianbi* with warm wine at the onset of the episode.

For malaria: Take one hundred *taoren* (peach kernels), remove the skin and tips, grind finely in a mortar without contact with unboiled water, and form a paste. Add three *qian* of *huangdan* (yellow lead oxide) and form pills the size of *wutou* seeds. Take three pills on the day of onset, swallowing with warm wine while facing north. If wine is not consumed, well-drawn water may be used instead. Prepare on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month at noon. Avoid chickens, dogs, and women during preparation.

Another formula: Take any amount of *xiaosuan* (garlic), grind thoroughly, mix with a small amount of *huangdan* until cohesive, and form pills the size of *jitou* (foxnut). Once dry, take one pill with freshly drawn water while facing east. Most effective.

**Chapter Seventeen: Remedies for Sudden Onset of Manic-Depressive Illness**

For sudden manic illness: Moxa three cones at the center of the penis. Recovery follows when urination becomes unobstructed.

Another remedy: Moxa three cones on the penis and fourteen cones at the seam below the scrotum.

Another remedy: Moxa three cones on each nipple, seven cones at the base of the big toe where the hairs converge, and seven cones at the base of the little toe.

Another remedy: Take one *sheng* of *tingli* (lepidium seed), pound three thousand times, hang a white dog upside down, strike it with a stick to draw blood, and mix with the *tingli* powder. Take one pill the size of a hemp seed, three doses to cure.

Another remedy: Steep three *sheng* of *langdang* (henbane) seeds in five *sheng* of wine, remove and dry, repeating until the wine is exhausted. Pound into powder and take one *qianbi* three times daily. Do not exceed the dose, as it may worsen mania.

Another formula from *Xiaopin*: The *Langdang* powder for manic-depressive illness. Take three *sheng* of *langdang* seeds, grind into powder, steep in one *sheng* of wine for several days, remove, pound, mix with the original liquid, strain, and simmer over hot water until it can be formed into pills. Take three pills the size of small beans three times daily. The face and mouth will feel tight, and there may be a sensation of insects moving in the head, with redness appearing on the forehead, hands, and feet—these are signs of impending recovery. If not observed, continue until the formula is finished.

Another remedy: Grind *fangkui* (ledebouriella) and take one to two *daogui* with warm wine. Numbness and slight insensitivity of the body indicate efficacy.

Another remedy: Burn the rope of a person who died by hanging and take three pinches of the ash.

Generally, for manic illness: When an episode occurs, the patient falls to the ground, foams at the mouth, loses consciousness, and upon being forcibly lifted, behaves wildly, even soiling themselves. Such cases are difficult to treat.

For sudden mania: Burn a toad, pound into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* three times daily with wine.

Another remedy: Lay the patient on the ground and pour cold water on their face continuously for an entire day.

For sudden raving or ghostly speech: Insert a needle slightly under the toenail of the big toe to stop the symptoms.

chunks.original_text: 又方，以甑带急合缚两手，火灸左右胁，握肘头文俱起七壮，须臾，鬼语自道姓名，乞去，徐徐诂问，乃解手耳。 凡狂发则欲走，或自高贵称神圣，皆应备诸火炙，乃得永差耳。 若或悲泣呻吟者，此为邪魅非狂，自依邪方治之，《近效方》已生蚕纸作灰，酒水任下，差疗风癫也。 附方 《斗门方》：治癫痫，用艾於阴囊下谷道正门当中间，随年道#2灸之。 《千金方》：治风癫百病，麻人四升，水六升，猛火煮，令牙生，去滓，煎取七合，旦空心服，或发或不发，或多言语，勿怪之，但人摩手足须定，凡进三剂愈。 又方，治狂邪发无时，披头大叫，欲杀人，不避水火，苦参以蜜丸如梧子大，每服十丸，薄荷汤下。 《外台秘要》：治风痫，引胁牵痛，发作则吐，耳如蝉鸣，天门冬，去心皮，曝乾，捣筛，酒服方寸匕。 若人久服，亦能长生。 《广利方》：治心热风痫，烂龙角，浓研汁，食上服二合，日再服。 《经验后方》：治大人小儿久患风痫，缠喉□嗽，遍身风疹，急中涎潮。 等此药不太吐逆，只出涎水，小儿服一字。 瓜蒂不限多少，细碾为末，壮年一字，十五已下、老怯半#3字，早晨井花水下，一食须含沙糖一块，良久涎如水出，年深涎尽，有一块如涎布，水上如鉴矣，涎尽食粥一两日，如吐多困甚，即咽麝香汤一盏，即止矣。 麝细斫，温水调下。 昔天平尚书觉昏眩，即服之，取涎有效。 《明皇杂录》云：开元中有名医纪朋者，观人颜色谈笑，知病深浅，不待诊脉。 帝闻之，召於掖庭中，看一宫人，每日昃#4则笑歌啼号，若狂疾，而足不能履地，朋视之日：此必因食饱而大促力，顿仆於地而然。 乃饮以云母汤，令熟寐，觉而失所苦，问之乃言：因太华公主载诞，宫中大陈歌吹，某乃主讴，惧其声不能清且长，吃□蹄羹饱，而当筵歌大曲，曲罢觉胸中甚热，戏於砌台上，高而坠下，久而方惺，病狂足不能及地。 治卒得惊邪恍惚方第十八 治人心下虚悸方，麻黄、半夏等分，捣，蜜丸，服如大豆三丸#5，日二#6，稍增之。 半夏汤洗去滑，乾。 治惊忧怖迫遥#7，或惊恐失财，或激愤惆怅，致志气错越，心行违僻不得安定者。 龙骨、远志、茯#8神、防风、牡蛎各二两，甘草七两，大枣七枚，以水八升，煮取二升，分再服，日日作之，取差。 又方，茯苓#9、乾地黄各四两，人参、桂#10各三两，甘草二两，麦门冬一升，去心，半夏六两，洗滑，生姜一斤，以水一斗，又杀乌鸡取血及肝心，煮三升，分四服，日三夜一，其问少食无爽，作三剂差。 又方，白雄鸡一头，治如食，真珠四两切，薤白四两，以水三升，煮取二升，宿勿食，旦悉鸡等及饮汁尽。 又有镇心定志诸丸，在大方中。 治卒中邪鬼，恍惚振噤方，灸鼻下人中，及两手足大指爪甲本，令艾丸在穴上，各七壮，不止，至十四#11壮愈。 此事本在杂治中。 治女人与邪物交通，独言独笑，悲思恍惚者、末#12雄黄一两，以松脂二两溶和，虎爪搅，令如弹丸，夜内火笼中烧之，令女人侵坐其上，被急自蒙，唯出头耳，一尔未差，不过三剂，过自断也。 又方，雄黄一两，人参一两，防风一两，五味子一升，捣筛，清旦以井水服方寸匕，三服差。
chunks.translated_text:
Another remedy: Bind the patient’s two hands tightly together with a steamer’s belt, then apply moxibustion to both flanks. Grasp the elbow tips and cauterize both points simultaneously, seven cones each. After a short while, the demon will speak its name and beg to leave. Gently question it, then untie the hands.

Generally, when mania erupts, the patient may run wildly or claim exalted status, calling themselves divine or sacred. In all such cases, apply moxibustion extensively to achieve lasting recovery. If the patient instead weeps, moans, or sighs, this indicates demonic possession rather than mania, and should be treated according to methods for demonic afflictions.

*The Effective Remedies of Recent Times* states: Burn paper used in silkworm rearing to ash, and take with wine or water to cure wind-induced mania.

**Additional Remedies**
*From the *Doumen Prescriptions*:* To treat epilepsy, apply moxibustion to the perineum at the midpoint between the anus and scrotum, one cone per year of age.

*From the *Thousand Gold Prescriptions*:* For wind-induced epilepsy and all manner of illnesses, boil four *sheng* of hemp seeds in six *sheng* of water over high heat until the seeds split. Strain and reduce to seven *ge*, then take on an empty stomach at dawn. The patient may experience episodes, remain silent, or speak excessively—do not be alarmed. Simply massage their hands and feet until they calm. Three doses will bring recovery.

Another remedy: For sudden onset of manic possession—where the patient tears their hair, screams wildly, and attempts to harm others without regard for fire or water—form *ku shen* (sophora root) into pills the size of firmiana seeds with honey. Take ten pills per dose with mint decoction.

*From the *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*:* For wind-induced epilepsy with pulling pain in the flanks, episodes of vomiting, and tinnitus like cicadas, remove the heart and peel of *tian men dong* (asparagus root), dry in the sun, grind to powder, and take one *fangcunbi* with wine. Prolonged use also promotes longevity.

*From the *Extensive Beneficial Prescriptions*:* For heat-induced wind epilepsy, thoroughly grind *lan long jiao* (decayed dragon’s horn) and take two *ge* of the thick juice before meals, twice daily.

*From the *Proven Later Prescriptions*:* For adults and children suffering long-term wind epilepsy, throat-constricting coughs, or full-body wind rashes with sudden drooling: This remedy induces minimal vomiting, only expelling saliva. For children, administer one *zi*. Grind *gua di* (melon stalk) to a fine powder without limit. Adults take one *zi*; those under fifteen or the elderly and weak take half. Administer in the morning with well-flower water, and have the patient hold a piece of rock sugar in their mouth. After a while, saliva will flow like water. In chronic cases, once all saliva is expelled, a piece resembling a saliva cloth will float on the water like a mirror. When the saliva is fully drained, consume congee for a day or two. If vomiting becomes excessive and the patient weakens, drink a cup of musk decoction to stop it. Finely chop musk and take with warm water.

Formerly, the Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices suffered from dizziness and took this remedy, expelling saliva with success.

*The Miscellaneous Records of Emperor Ming* states: During the Kaiyuan era, a renowned physician named Ji Peng could diagnose illness by observing a patient’s complexion and speech, without needing to take their pulse. The emperor, having heard of him, summoned him to the palace to examine a concubine who, every afternoon, would laugh, sing, weep, and scream as if mad, yet could not stand. Ji Peng observed her and said: “This must have resulted from overeating followed by sudden exertion, causing her to collapse.” He administered a cloud-mother decoction, had her sleep deeply, and upon waking, her suffering was gone. When asked, she recounted: “During the grand celebration for Princess Taihua’s birth, the palace hosted a grand musical performance. I was the lead singer and, fearing my voice would not be clear and sustained, ate a full bowl of pig’s trotter stew before performing. After singing a long piece, I felt intense heat in my chest. While playing on the terrace, I fell from a height. It was a long while before I regained consciousness, and since then, I have suffered from madness and been unable to stand.”

**Chapter Eighteen: Remedies for Sudden Fright, Demonic Possession, and Confusion**

For palpitations due to heart deficiency: Grind equal parts *ma huang* (ephedra) and *ban xia* (pinellia), form into honey pills, and take three pills the size of soybeans, twice daily, gradually increasing the dose. Wash *ban xia* to remove slipperiness and dry before use.

For distress caused by shock, sorrow, or terror—such as sudden loss of wealth, or pent-up frustration leading to mental disarray, erratic behavior, and restlessness: Combine two *liang* each of *long gu* (dragon bone), *yuan zhi* (polygala), *fu shen* (poria spirit), *fang feng* (saposhnikovia), and *mu li* (oyster shell); seven *liang* of *gan cao* (licorice); and seven *da zao* (jujubes). Boil in eight *sheng* of water, reduce to two *sheng*, and divide into two doses. Prepare daily until recovery.

Another remedy: Four *liang* each of *fu ling* (poria) and *gan di huang* (dried rehmannia); three *liang* each of *ren shen* (ginseng) and *gui* (cinnamon); two *liang* of *gan cao*; one *sheng* of *mai men dong* (ophiopogon), with the heart removed; six *liang* of *ban xia*, washed to remove slipperiness; and one *jin* of *sheng jiang* (fresh ginger). Boil in one *dou* of water with the blood and liver of a black hen, reduce to three *sheng*, and divide into four doses—three during the day and one at night. During treatment, eat lightly and avoid rich foods. Three doses will bring recovery.

Another remedy: Prepare a white rooster as for eating, cut four *liang* of *zhen zhu* (pearl) and four *liang* of *xie bai* (Chinese garlic chives), and boil in three *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng*. Fast overnight, then consume the entire chicken and broth at dawn.

Other calming and mind-stabilizing pills are recorded in the major prescriptions.

For sudden demonic possession with confusion and chills: Apply moxibustion to the *ren zhong* point below the nose and at the base of the thumbnail on both big toes and thumbs, seven cones each. If symptoms persist, increase to fourteen cones.

This method originally appeared in the miscellaneous treatments.

For women who communicate with demonic entities, speaking or laughing alone, or experiencing sorrow and confusion: Grind one *liang* of *xiong huang* (realgar) and mix with two *liang* of melted pine resin. Stir with a tiger’s claw until the size of a bullet, then burn in a fire basket at night. Have the woman sit over it, covering herself tightly with a blanket, leaving only her head exposed. If not cured after one attempt, repeat up to three times, after which the demon will sever ties on its own.

Another remedy: Grind one *liang* each of *xiong huang*, *ren shen* (ginseng), and *fang feng* (saposhnikovia) with one *sheng* of *wu wei zi* (schisandra). Sift and take one *fangcunbi* with well water at dawn. Three doses will bring recovery.

chunks.original_text: 师往以针五枚内头髻中，狂病者则以器贮水，三赤新布覆之，横大刀於上，悉乃矜庄，呼见其人，其人必欲起走，慎勿听，因取一喷之，一呵视，三通乃熟，拭去水，指弹额上近发际，问欲愈乎？ 其人必不肯答，如此二七弹乃答，欲因杖针刺鼻下人中近孔内侧，空停针，两耳根前宛宛动中停针，又削鼻直上入发际一寸，横针又刺鼻直上入，乃具诘问，怜怜醒悟，则乃止矣。 若男女喜梦与鬼通致恍惚者，锯截鹿角屑，酒服三指撮，日三。 附方 张仲景：主心下悸，半夏、麻黄丸。 二物等分，末，蜜丸如小豆，每服三丸，日三。 《简要济众方》：每心藏不安，惊悸善忘，上鬲风热化痰。 白石英一两，朱砂一两，同研为散，每服半钱，食后夜卧，金银汤调下。 心中客热，膀胱间连胁下气妨，常旦忧愁不乐，兼心忪者。 取莎草根二大斤，切熬令香、以生绢袋贮之，於三大斗无灰清酒中浸之，春三月浸一日，即堪服，冬十月后，即七日，近暖处乃佳。 每空腹服一盏，日夜三四服之，常令酒气相续，以知为度。 若不饮酒，即取莎草根十两，加桂心五两，芜萸三两，和捣为散，以蜜和为丸，捣一千杵，丸如梧子大，每空腹以酒及姜蜜汤饮汁等下二十丸，服，渐加至三十丸，以差为度。 治中风诸急方第十九 治卒中急风，闷乱欲死方。 灸两足大指下横文中，随年壮，又别有续命汤。 若毒急不得行者，内筋急者。 灸内踝，外筋急者，灸外踝上，二十壮。 若有肿痹，虚者取白敛二分，附子一分，捣，服半刀圭，每日可三服。 若眼上睛垂者，灸目两毗后，三壮。 若不识人者，灸季胁头，各七壮，此胁小肋屈头也。 不能语者，灸第二槌，或第五槌上，五十壮。 又别有不得语方，在后篇中矣。 又方，豉、茱萸各一升，水五升，煮取二升，稍稍服。 若眼反口噤，腹中切痛者，灸阴囊下第一横理，十四壮。 又别有服膏之方。 若狂走欲斫刺人，或欲自杀，骂晋不息，称鬼语者。 灸两口吻头赤肉际各一壮，又灸两肘屈中五壮，又灸背胛中间三壮，三日报灸三，仓公秘法，又应灸阴囊下缝三十壮。 又别有狂邪方。 若发狂者，取车毂中脂如鸡子，热温淳苦酒，以投脂甚搅令消，服之令尽。 若心烦恍惚，腹中痛满，或时绝而复苏者。 取釜下土五升，捣筛，以冷水八升和之，取汁，尽服之，口已噤者，强开，以竹筒灌之，使得下，人便愈，甚妙。 若身体角弓反张，四肢不随，烦乱欲死者。 清酒五升，鸡白矢一升，捣筛合和，扬之千遍，乃饮之，大人服一升，日三，少小五合，差。 若头身无不痛，颠倒烦满欲死者。 取头垢如大豆大服之，并囊贮大豆，蒸熟，逐痛处熨之，作两囊更番为佳。 若无豆，亦可蒸鼠壤土熨。 若但腹中切痛者，取盐半斤，熬令尽，着口中，饮热汤二升，得便吐愈。 又方，附子六分，生姜三两，切，以水二升，煮取一升，分为再服。 若手足不随方，取青布烧作姻，就小口器中熏痛处。 又方，豉三升，水九升，煮取三升，分三服。 又，取豉一升，微熬，囊贮渍三升酒中三宿，温服，微令醉为佳。 若身中有掣痛，不仁不随处者。 取乾艾叶一紏许，丸之，内瓦甑下，塞余孔，唯留一目，以痛处着饭目，下烧艾以黑之，一时间愈矣。

The master would insert five needles into the topknot of the patient’s hair. For those with manic illness, a vessel of water was prepared, covered with three layers of new red cloth, and a large knife laid horizontally atop it. Assuming a solemn demeanor, the master would call the patient forth. The afflicted would invariably attempt to rise and flee, but the master would not permit it. Instead, he would take a mouthful of water and spray it upon the patient, then exhale sharply while gazing intently—repeating this three times until the patient was thoroughly drenched. Wiping away the water, he would flick the patient’s forehead near the hairline with his finger and ask, “Do you wish to be cured?” The patient would refuse to answer, so the master would repeat the flicking twice seven times before receiving a response. Then, using a staff-like needle, he would pierce the area beneath the nose, beside the philtrum near the nostrils, leaving the needle in place. He would next insert needles into the hollows before both ear roots, again leaving them in place. Finally, he would measure one *cun* upward from the bridge of the nose into the hairline and insert a needle horizontally, then pierce straight upward from the nose into the same point. Only after these procedures would he thoroughly question the patient. Once the patient awoke in clarity and remorse, the treatment would cease.

For men or women who frequently dream of intercourse with spirits, leading to confusion and disorientation: Saw deer antler into fine shavings and take three pinches with wine, three times daily.

**Attached Remedies**
Zhang Zhongjing’s remedy for palpitations below the heart: *Ban xia* and *ma huang* pills. Grind equal parts of the two ingredients into powder, form into honey pills the size of small beans, and take three pills each time, three times daily.

*Jian Yao Ji Zhong Fang*: For unsettled heart *zang*, fright palpitations, and forgetfulness—upper diaphragm wind-heat transforming into phlegm. Grind one *liang* each of white quartz and cinnabar into powder. Take half a *qian* each time after meals and before bed, mixed with gold or silver-infused water.

For guest heat in the heart, qi obstruction between the bladder and ribs, constant morning sorrow, and unease with palpitations: Take two large *jin* of *sha cao* root, slice and roast until fragrant, then place in a raw silk pouch. Steep in three large *dou* of ash-free clear wine. In spring, soak for one day before drinking; after the tenth month, soak for seven days, keeping the vessel in a warm place. Drink one cup on an empty stomach, three or four times day and night, ensuring the wine’s influence remains continuous. Adjust dosage as needed. For those who do not drink wine, take ten *liang* of *sha cao* root, five *liang* of *gui xin*, and three *liang* of *wu yu*, grind into powder, and form into honey pills with one thousand pestle strikes, each the size of a *wu* seed. Take twenty pills on an empty stomach with wine or ginger-honey decoction, gradually increasing to thirty pills until recovery.

**Chapter Nineteen: Remedies for Sudden Wind Stroke and Acute Conditions**
For sudden wind stroke with suffocating confusion and near-death: Moxibustion at the transverse crease beneath the big toe, one cone per year of age. Another remedy is the *Xu Ming* decoction.

If the poison is acute and mobility impaired, with inner sinew tension: Moxibustion at the inner ankle. For outer sinew tension: Moxibustion above the outer ankle, twenty cones.

For swelling and numbness due to deficiency: Grind two parts *bai lian* and one part *fu zi* into powder. Take half a *dao gui* each time, up to three doses daily.

If the eyes roll upward with the pupils obscured: Moxibustion behind both outer canthi, three cones.

For inability to recognize people: Moxibustion at the tips of the floating ribs, seven cones each (the floating ribs are the curved ends of the lower ribs).

For inability to speak: Moxibustion on the second or fifth vertebra, fifty cones.

Another remedy for speechlessness appears in a later chapter.

Another remedy: Boil one *sheng* each of fermented soybeans and *zhu yu* in five *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Sip gradually.

For upward-rolling eyes, lockjaw, and acute abdominal pain: Moxibustion at the first transverse crease below the scrotum, fourteen cones.

Another remedy involves consuming medicinal pastes.

For those who rage, attempt to stab or kill others, or contemplate suicide, ceaselessly cursing and speaking in ghostly tongues: Moxibustion at the red flesh at the corners of both lips, one cone each. Also moxa the creases of both elbows, five cones each, and the space between the shoulder blades, three cones. Repeat the moxibustion three times over three days. This is Cang Gong’s secret method. Additionally, moxibustion at the seam beneath the scrotum, thirty cones.

Other remedies for manic possession appear elsewhere.

For those who become manic: Take axle grease the size of a chicken egg, heat it in bitter wine, and stir until dissolved. Consume the entire mixture.

For heart vexation, confusion, abdominal fullness and pain, or intermittent loss of consciousness: Take five *sheng* of soot from beneath a cauldron, grind and sift, then mix with eight *sheng* of cold water. Strain and drink the entire liquid. If the patient’s jaw is locked, force it open and administer the liquid through a bamboo tube to ensure it is swallowed. The patient will recover immediately—this method is highly effective.

For opisthotonos with arched back, loss of limb control, and near-death from vexation: Mix five *sheng* of clear wine with one *sheng* of chicken droppings, grind and sift, then whisk a thousand times. Adults take one *sheng* three times daily; children take five *ge*. Recovery will follow.

For unbearable pain throughout the head and body, with disorientation and near-death from vexation: Take head filth the size of a large soybean and swallow it. Additionally, fill two pouches with steamed soybeans and alternate applying them as hot compresses to the painful areas. If soybeans are unavailable, steam mouse burrow soil and apply similarly.

For acute abdominal pain: Roast half a *jin* of salt until exhausted, place it in the mouth, then drink two *sheng* of hot water to induce vomiting. Recovery will follow.

Another remedy: Slice six parts *fu zi* and three *liang* of fresh ginger, boil in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, and divide into two doses.

For loss of limb control: Burn green cloth to produce smoke and fumigate the affected area using a small-mouthed vessel.

Another remedy: Boil three *sheng* of fermented soybeans in nine *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain, and divide into three doses.

Another: Lightly roast one *sheng* of fermented soybeans, place in a pouch, and steep in three *sheng* of wine for three nights. Drink warm, enough to induce mild intoxication.

For localized spasms, numbness, and loss of control: Roll a handful of dried mugwort leaves into a ball, place it beneath a clay steamer, and seal all but one opening. Position the painful area over the open hole and burn the mugwort beneath it until the skin blackens. Recovery will occur within an hour.

For clenched jaw that will not open: Take five *sheng* of soybeans, roast until yellow-black, steep in five *sheng* of wine, and extract the liquid. Force the mouth open with an implement and pour the liquid in, then induce sweating.

Another remedy: Four *liang* of *duhuo*, two *liang* of cinnamon, boiled in two *sheng* of wine and water to yield one and a half *sheng*. Divide into three doses, administer while the mouth is open, then have the patient lie warmly covered and apply moxibustion to induce sweating.

For rigidity of the body with inability to bend, stretch, or turn: Cut yellow-white *huai* bark into pieces, boil in six *sheng* of wine and water to yield two *sheng*, strain, and administer in small doses at an appropriate temperature.

Another remedy: Scrape one *sheng* of *zhi* tree bark, steep in one *sheng* of wine overnight, and consume from five *ge* to one *sheng*. When the wine is finished, prepare more—recovery will follow.

For facial distortion with deviated mouth: Apply moxibustion to the horizontal crease at the corner of the mouth. Remove the moxa as soon as heat is felt—do not burn completely, as excessive application will overcorrect. If the left side is distorted, moxa the right corner; if the right side is distorted, moxa the left.

Another method: Moxa a single cone on the upper joint of the middle finger—if the distortion is to the right, moxa the left finger. Additional moxibustion methods for deviated mouth follow later.

Another remedy: Take powdered *kongqing* and place it in the mouth—swallowing it will immediately restore normality. (Identical to Yao’s method.)

Another remedy: Rub spider eggs on the tense cheek near the jaw until the mouth returns to normal—stop when alignment is achieved. Alternatively, warm the eggs by the fire before rubbing.

Another remedy: Grind equal parts oyster shell, alum, aconite, and yellow earth from a stove, mix with the blood of a three-year-old rooster’s comb, and apply to the tense side. Hold water nearby; when the mouth begins to realign, promptly wash off the medicine. Do not reapply once corrected.

Another remedy: Apply a mixture of turtle shell and *wutou*—remove immediately when the mouth begins to realign.

For cold extremities, clear fluid vomiting, and writhing with cries: Take one *liang* of cinnamon, break into pieces, boil in three *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng*, strain, and consume the entire dose at an appropriate temperature.

For joint pain: Grind eight *liang* of cattail pollen with one *liang* of roasted aconite. Take one *qian* initially, three times daily, gradually increasing to one *fangcunchi*.

For painful, restless joints that resist bending or stretching, with pain upon touch, shortness of breath, sweating, or swelling: Two *liang* of aconite, four *liang* of cinnamon, three *liang* of *zhu*, and two *liang* of licorice, boiled in six *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng*. Divide into three doses—recovery follows sweating.

For sudden wind strike with profuse cold sweating like water: Grind equal parts gypsum and licorice, and take one *fangcunchi* with wine. Repeat the dose when the sun has moved one *zhang*.

For gradual wind strike with loss of limb control: Boil three *sheng* of fermented soybeans in nine *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng*, and divide into three doses. Prepare twice daily. Alternatively, steep in wine and consume.

chunks.original_text: 若卒中风瘫，身体不自收，不能语，迷昧不知人者，陈元狸#21骨膏至要，在备急药方中。 附方头风头痛附 《经验方》：治急中风，目#22瞑牙噤，无门下药者，用此末子，以中指点末，揩齿三二十，揩大牙左右，其口自开，始得下药，名 开关散：天南星捣为末，白龙脑，二件各等分，研，自五月五日午时合，患者只一字至半钱。 《简要济众》：治中风噤不开，涎潮吐方。 用皂角一挺，去皮，涂猪脂，炙令黄色，为末，每服一钱匕，非时温酒服。 如气实脉大，调二钱匕。 如牙关不开，用白梅揩齿，口开即灌药，以吐出风涎，差。 治中风不省人事，牙关紧急者。 藜芦一两，去芦头，浓煎，防风汤浴过，焙乾，碎切，炒微褐#23色，捣为末#24，每服半钱，温水调下，以吐出风涎为效。 如人行二里未吐，再服。 又治胆风毒气，虚实不调，昏沉睡多。 酸枣人一两，生用，金挺蜡茶二两，以生姜汁涂，炙令微焦，捣罗为散，每服二钱，水七分，煎六分，无时温服。 《孙尚药》：治卒中风，昏昏若醉，形体昏闷，四肢不收，或倒或不倒，或口角似斜，微有涎出，斯须不治，便为大病，故伤人也，此证风涎潮於上膈，痹气不通，宜用 急救稀涎散：猪牙皂角四挺，须是肥实不蚛，削去黑皮，晋矾一两，光明通莹者，二味同捣，罗为细末，再研为散。 如有患者，可服半钱，重者三字匕，温水调灌下，不大呕吐，只是微微涎稀令出，或一升二升，当时惺惺，次缓而调治，不可便大段治，恐过伤人命。 累经效，不能尽述。 《梅师方》：疗瘫缓风，手足亸曳，口眼喎斜，语言赛涩，履步不正。 神验乌龙丹：川乌头去皮脐了，五灵脂各五两，右为末，入龙脑、麝香，研令细匀，滴水丸如弹子大，每服一丸，先以生姜汁研化，次暖酒调服之，一日两服，空心晚食前服，治一人只三十丸，服得五七丸，便觉抬得手，移得步，十丸可以自#25。 《圣惠方》：治一切风疾，若能久服，轻身明目，黑髭驻颜。 用南烛树，春夏取枝叶，秋冬取根皮，拣择细锉，五升，水五斗，慢火煎取二斗，去滓，别於净锅中慢火煎如稀饧，以瓷瓶贮，温酒下一匙，日三服。 又方，治风立有奇效。 用木天蓼一斤，去皮，细锉，以生绢袋贮，好酒二斗浸之，春夏一七日，秋冬二七日后开，每空心，日午初夜合温饮一盏，老幼临时加减，若长服，日只每朝一盏。 又方，治中风口喎。 巴豆七枚，去皮烂研，喎左涂右手心，喎右涂左手心，仍以暖水一盏，安向手心，须臾即便正，洗去药，并频抽掣中指。 又方，治风头旋。 用蝉壳二两，微炒为末，非时温酒下一钱匕。 《千金方》：治中风，面目相引，偏僻牙车急，舌不可转。 桂心以酒煮取汁，故布蘸拓病上，即正，左喎拓右，右喎拓左，常用大效。 又方，治三年中风不较#26者。 松叶一斤，细切之，以酒一斗，煮取三升，顿服，取汗出，立差。 又方，立卒中风头面肿，杵杏人如膏傅之。 又方，治头面风，眼□鼻塞，眼暗冷泪。 杏#27人三升，为末，水煮四五沸，洗头冷汗，尽三度差。 《外台秘要》：治卒中风口喎。 皂角五两，去皮为末，三年大醋和，右喎涂左，右喎涂右，乾及#28傅之，差。

If suddenly struck by wind-induced paralysis, with the body unable to control itself, speechlessness, and confusion rendering one unable to recognize others, the marrow fat of an aged leopard cat is most essential—this is found in the *Emergency Remedies* section.

**Additional Formulas for Head Wind and Headache**
From *Tested Formulas*: To treat acute wind strike with eyes closed, clenched jaw, and no way to administer medicine, use this powder. Dip the middle finger into the powder and rub the teeth thirty to forty times, focusing on the molars on both sides—the mouth will open on its own, allowing medicine to be given. Named *Opening the Pass Powder*: Grind *tiannanxing* into powder, mix with borneol in equal parts, and prepare on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month at noon. For the afflicted, administer from one *zi* to half a *qian*.

From *Concise Aid for the Multitudes*: For wind strike with clenched jaw and foaming saliva.
Use one *zhi* of *zaojiao*, remove the skin, coat with lard, and roast until yellow. Grind into powder and take one *qianbi* with warm wine at any time. If the pulse is strong and large, adjust the dose to two *qianbi*. If the jaw remains locked, rub the teeth with a white plum—the mouth will open, allowing the medicine to be administered to induce vomiting of wind saliva, leading to recovery.

To treat wind strike with loss of consciousness and tightly clenched jaw.
Use one *liang* of *lilu*, remove the root, boil in a strong decoction of *fangfeng*, bathe, dry, cut finely, and stir-fry until slightly brown. Grind into powder and take half a *qian* with warm water, inducing vomiting of wind saliva as the effect. If no vomiting occurs after walking two *li*, administer again. Also treats gallbladder wind toxin, disharmony of deficiency and excess, and excessive drowsiness.
Use one *liang* of raw *suanzaoren* and two *liang* of *jinting* wax tea, coat with fresh ginger juice, and roast until slightly scorched. Grind into powder and take two *qian* each time, boiling in seven *fen* of water to yield six *fen*, and consume warm at any time.

From *Sun Shangyao’s Remedies*: To treat sudden wind strike with a drunken stupor, bodily heaviness, limbs unresponsive, or falling without falling, or a slanted mouth with slight drooling—if left untreated even briefly, it becomes a grave illness, thus harming the person. This condition arises from wind saliva congesting the upper diaphragm, obstructing the flow of *qi*. The *Emergency Salvation Thin-Saliva Powder* is recommended:
Four *ting* of pig’s tusk *zaojiao* (must be plump and unblemished, with black skin removed), one *liang* of *jin fan* (clear and lustrous), grind both together, sift into fine powder, and grind again into a fine preparation. For the afflicted, administer half a *qian*; for severe cases, three *zi*. Mix with warm water and administer. It does not cause violent vomiting but only gently thins the saliva, allowing one to two *sheng* to be expelled, restoring clarity. Follow with gradual treatment—do not rush into aggressive therapy, lest it harm the patient’s life. Its repeated efficacy cannot be fully described.

From *Master Mei’s Formulas*: To treat flaccid wind paralysis, with dragging limbs, slanted mouth and eyes, slurred speech, and unsteady gait.
The *Divinely Effective Black Dragon Elixir*: Five *liang* each of *chuanwu* (with skin and navel removed) and *wulingzhi*. Grind into powder, add borneol and musk, and grind finely. Form into pills the size of a bullet with water. For each dose, first dissolve one pill in fresh ginger juice, then mix with warm wine and consume. Take twice daily, on an empty stomach and before the evening meal. For one person, thirty pills suffice—after five to seven pills, one can lift the hands and move the feet; ten pills allow self-sufficiency.

From *Sagely Benefit Formulas*: To treat all wind illnesses. If taken over time, it lightens the body, sharpens the eyes, darkens the beard, and preserves youthful appearance.
Use the *nanzhu* tree: in spring and summer, take the branches and leaves; in autumn and winter, take the root bark. Select and finely chop five *sheng*, boil in five *dou* of water to yield two *dou*, strain, and simmer the liquid in a clean pot until it thickens like syrup. Store in a porcelain bottle and take one spoonful with warm wine, three times daily.

Another formula, with miraculous efficacy against wind.
Use one *jin* of *mutianliao*, remove the skin, and finely chop. Place in a raw silk bag and steep in two *dou* of good wine. After seven days in spring and summer, or fourteen days in autumn and winter, open and consume. Take one cup each on an empty stomach, at noon, and in the early evening, adjusting the dose for the elderly and young. For long-term use, take only one cup each morning.

Another formula for wind-induced slanted mouth.
Crush seven *badou*, remove the skin, and apply the paste: if the mouth slants left, apply to the right palm; if right, apply to the left palm. Place a cup of warm water over the palm—the mouth will straighten. Wash off the medicine and repeatedly pull the middle finger.

Another formula for wind-induced vertigo.
Use two *liang* of cicada moltings, lightly stir-fry, and grind into powder. Take one *qianbi* with warm wine at any time.

From *Essential Formulas Worth a Thousand Gold*: To treat wind strike with facial distortion, clenched jaw, and an immobile tongue.
Boil *guixin* in wine to extract the juice, soak a cloth, and apply to the affected area—the condition will correct. If the left side is slanted, apply to the right; if the right, apply to the left. Consistently effective.

Another formula for wind stroke persisting for three years.
Finely chop one *jin* of pine needles, boil in one *dou* of wine to yield three *sheng*, and consume in one dose to induce sweating—immediate recovery.

Another formula for sudden wind strike with facial swelling.
Pound apricot kernels into a paste and apply.

Another formula for head and facial wind, with eye and nasal congestion, dim vision, and cold tears.
Grind three *sheng* of apricot kernels into powder, boil in water for four to five cycles, and wash the head until cold sweat is induced. Repeat three times for recovery.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat sudden wind strike with slanted mouth.
Grind five *liang* of *zaojiao* (skin removed) into powder, mix with three-year-old vinegar, and apply: if the mouth slants left, apply to the right; if right, apply to the left. Reapply as it dries—recovery follows.

chunks.original_text: 又，治偏风及一切风。 桑枝锉一大升，用今年新嫩枝，以水一大斗，煎取二大升，夏用井中沉，恐酢坏，每日服一盏，空心服，尽又煎服，终身不患偏风。 若预防风，能服一大升佳。 又主#29风身体如虫行。 盐一斗，水一石，煎减半，澄清，温洗三五度，治一切风。 葛氏方，治中风寒瘟，直口噤，不知人。 鸡屎白一升，熬令黄，极热，以酒三升，和搅去滓服。 《千金翼方》：治热风汗出心闷，水和云母服之，不过再服，立差。 《箧中方》：治风头及脑掣痛不可禁者，摩膏主之。 取牛蒡茎叶捣，取浓汁二升，合无灰酒一升，盐花一匙头，火煎令稠成膏，以摩痛处，风毒散自止。 亦主时行头痛。 摩时须极力令作热，乃速效。 冬月无叶，用根代之亦可。 《经验后方》：治中风及壅滞，以旋覆花洗尘令诤，捣末，炼蜜丸，如梧子大，夜卧以茶汤下五丸至七丸、十丸。 又方，解风热，疏积热、风壅，消食，化气，导血，大解壅滞。 大黄四两，牵牛子四两，半生半熟，为末，炼蜜为丸，如梧子大，每服茶下一十丸，如要微动，吃十五丸，冬月宜服，并不搜搅人。 《集验方》：治风热心躁，口乾，狂言，浑身壮热及中诸毒，龙脑甘露丸。 寒水石半斤，烧半日，净地坑内，盆合四面，湿土壅起，候经宿取出，入甘草末、天竺黄各二两，龙脑二分，糯米膏丸，弹子大，蜜水磨下。 《食医心镜》：主#30中风心肺风热，手足不随，及风痹不任，筋脉五缓，恍惚烦躁。 熊肉一斤，切，如常法调和作腌腊，空腹食之。 又主风孪拘急偏枯，血气不通利。 雁肪四两，炼，泸过，每#31日空心暖酒一杯，肪一匙头，饮之。 同经曰：治历节诸风，骨节疼痛，昼夜不可忍者。 没药半两，研，虎脑骨三两，涂酥炙黄色，先捣，罗为散，与没药同#32研令细，温酒#33调二钱，日三服，大佳。 《圣惠方》：治历节风，百节疼痛不可忍。 用虎头骨一具，涂酥炙黄，槌碎，绢袋贮，用清酒二斗，浸五宿，随性多少，暖饮之，妙。 《外#34台秘要方》：疗历节诸风，百节酸痛不可忍，松脂三十斤，炼五十遍，不能五十遍，亦可二十遍，用以炼酥三升，温和松脂三升，熟搅令极稠，旦空腹以酒服方寸匕，日三，数食缅粥为佳。 慎血腥、生冷、酢物、果子一百日，差。 又方，松节酒，主历节风，四肢疼痛如解落。 松节二十斤，酒五斗，渍二七日，服一合，日五六服。 《斗门方》：治白虎风所患不以，积年久#35治无效，痛不可忍者。 用脑、麝、枫、柳皮不限多少，细锉焙乾，浸酒常服，以醉为度，即差。 今之寄生枫树上者，方堪用，其叶亦可制砒霜粉，尤妙矣。 《经验后方》：治白虎风，走注疼痛，两膝热肿。 虎胫骨涂酥炙、黑附子炮裂去皮脐各一两，为末，每服温酒调下二钱匕，日再服。 《外台秘要》：治疬疡风及三年。 酢磨乌贼鱼骨，先布磨，肉赤即傅之。 又治疬疡风，酢磨硫黄，傅之，止。 《圣惠方》：治疬疡风，用羊蹄菜根於生铁上，以好醋磨，旋旋刮取，涂於患上，未差，更入硫黄少许，同磨涂之。 《集验方》：治颈项及面上白驳，浸淫渐长，有似癣，但无疮可治，鳗鲡鱼脂傅之，先拭剥上，刮使燥痛后，以鱼脂傅之，一度便愈，甚者不过三度。

Another formula for hemiplegic wind and all wind disorders.
Cut one large *sheng* of mulberry twigs—use this year’s fresh, tender branches—boil in one large *dou* of water to yield two large *sheng*. In summer, chill the decoction in a well to prevent souring. Take one cup daily on an empty stomach. When the first batch is finished, decoct and consume again. Lifelong adherence prevents hemiplegic wind. For wind prevention, consuming one large *sheng* is optimal.

Another formula for wind-induced sensations of insects crawling over the body.
Boil one *dou* of salt in one *shi* of water until reduced by half. Clarify, then wash the body three to five times with the warm liquid—effective for all wind disorders.

From *Master Ge’s Formulas*: To treat wind strike with cold damage, lockjaw, and loss of consciousness.
Stir-fry one *sheng* of white chicken droppings until yellow and extremely hot. Mix with three *sheng* of wine, strain, and consume the liquid.

From *Supplement to the Thousand Golden Prescriptions*: For heat wind with sweating and heart vexation, mix mica with water and consume. Recovery follows after no more than two doses.

From *Formulas from the Satchel*: For wind-induced head and brain pain unbearable to endure, apply a massage ointment.
Pound burdock stems and leaves to extract two *sheng* of thick juice. Combine with one *sheng* of ash-free wine and a spoonful of salt crystals. Simmer over fire until thickened into an ointment, then massage onto painful areas. The wind toxin disperses and ceases. Also treats seasonal head pain. When massaging, apply force until heat is generated—rapid efficacy follows. In winter, when leaves are unavailable, roots may be substituted.

From *Tested Later Formulas*: For wind strike and congestion, grind washed, clean *xuanfuhua* (inula flower) into powder, mix with refined honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. At bedtime, take five to ten pills with tea.

Another formula to resolve wind-heat, disperse accumulated heat and wind congestion, promote digestion, transform *qi*, guide blood, and thoroughly resolve congestion.
Grind four *liang* of rhubarb and four *liang* of morning glory seeds (half raw, half parched) into powder. Mix with refined honey to form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten pills with tea; if mild purgation is desired, take fifteen. Suitable for winter use—does not disturb the person.

From *Collected Verified Formulas*: For wind-heat with heart agitation, dry mouth, raving speech, generalized high fever, and various poisonings, use *Dragon Brain Sweet Dew Pills*.
Burn half a *jin* of *hanshuishi* (calcium sulfate) for half a day. Bury in a clean earthen pit, cover with a basin, and mound wet soil around it. After one night, retrieve and add two *liang* each of licorice powder and *tianzhu huang* (bamboo silica), plus two *fen* of *longnao* (borneol). Form into pills the size of longan seeds with glutinous rice paste. Dissolve in honey water and consume.

From *Heart Mirror of Dietary Medicine*: For wind strike with heart and lung wind-heat, loss of limb control, wind impediment with unbearable symptoms, flaccid sinews and vessels, disorientation, and vexation.
Cut one *jin* of bear meat and prepare as salted, cured jerky following standard methods. Consume on an empty stomach.

Another formula for wind-induced spasms, contractures, hemiplegia, and obstructed blood and *qi*.
Refine four *liang* of wild goose fat, strain, and take one spoonful daily on an empty stomach with a cup of warmed wine.

The same text states: For pervading wind with unbearable pain in all joints day and night.
Grind half a *liang* of *moyao* (myrrh) into powder. Roast three *liang* of tiger brain bone in *su* (refined butter) until yellow, then pound and sift into powder. Mix thoroughly with the *moyao*. Take two *qian* with warm wine, three times daily—highly effective.

From *Imperial Grace Formulary*: For pervading wind with unbearable pain in all joints.
Roast one tiger skull in *su* until yellow, then crush and place in a silk bag. Steep in two *dou* of clear wine for five nights. Drink warmed as desired—wondrously effective.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For pervading wind with unbearable sour pain in all joints.
Refine thirty *jin* of pine resin fifty times (or at least twenty times if fifty is unfeasible). Warm three *sheng* of refined *su* and blend with three *sheng* of pine resin, stirring until extremely thick. On an empty stomach, take one *fangcunbi* (spoonful) with wine, three times daily. Consume thin rice porridge frequently. Avoid blood, raw or cold foods, sour items, and fruits for one hundred days—recovery follows.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: *Pine Node Wine* for pervading wind with limb pain as if dislocated.
Steep twenty *jin* of pine nodes in five *dou* of wine for fourteen days. Take one *ge* (cup), five or six times daily.

From *Doumen’s Formulas*: For *White Tiger Wind* of any duration, even chronic cases unresponsive to treatment with unbearable pain.
Finely cut and dry-fry an unspecified quantity of *nao* (borneol), *she* (musk), *feng* (maple bark), and *liu* (willow bark). Steep in wine and consume until intoxicated—immediate recovery. The mistletoe growing on maple trees is particularly effective; its leaves can also be used to refine *pishuang* (arsenic powder)—especially potent.

From *Tested Later Formulas*: For *White Tiger Wind* with migrating pain and hot swelling in both knees.
Roast one *liang* each of tiger shin bone in *su* and black aconite (parched, skin and navel removed) into powder. Take two *qianbi* with warm wine, twice daily.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For scrofula wind and three-year cases.
Grind cuttlefish bone with vinegar and apply after first scrubbing the skin until red.

Another formula for scrofula wind: Grind sulfur with vinegar and apply—immediate cessation.

From *Imperial Grace Formulary*: For scrofula wind, grind sheep’s sorrel root on raw iron with good vinegar, scraping continuously to collect the liquid. Apply to the affected area. If unresolved, add a small amount of sulfur, grind together, and reapply.

From *Collected Verified Formulas*: For white patches on the neck and face that spread gradually like tinea but without sores, apply eel fat. First, scrub the affected area until dry and painful, then apply the fat. One application cures; severe cases require no more than three.

Grind three *sheng* of apricot kernels into powder, boil in water for four to five cycles, and wash the head until cold sweat is induced. Repeat three times for recovery.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: To treat sudden wind strike with slanted mouth.
Grind five *liang* of *zaojiao* (skin removed) into powder, mix with three-year-old vinegar, and apply: if the mouth slants left, apply to the right; if right, apply to the left. Reapply as it dries—recovery follows.

chunks.original_text: 《圣惠方》：治白驳，用蛇蜕，烧末醋调，傅上佳。 又方，治中风烦热，皮肤疡痒，用醍醐四两，每服酒调下宇#36匙。 《集验方》：治风气客於皮肤，瘙痒不已。 蜂房炙过，蝉蜕等分，为末，酒调一钱匕，日三二服。 又方，蝉蜕、薄苛等分，为末，酒调一钱匕，日三服。 《北梦琐言》云：有一朝士见梁奉御，诊之曰：风疾已深，请速归去。 朝士复见鄜州马医赵鄂者，复诊之，言疾危。 与梁所说同矣。 曰：只有一法，请官人试吃消梨，不限多少，咀齕不及，绞汁而饮。 到家旬日，唯吃消梨，顿爽矣。 《千金方》：治头风头痛，大豆三升，炒令无声，先以贮一斗二升，瓶一只，贮九升清酒，乘豆热即投於酒中，蜜泥封之七日，温服。 孙真人方，治头风痛，以豉汤洗头避风，即差。 《千金翼》：治头风，捣葶苈子，以汤淋取汁洗头上。 又主头风沐头，吴茱萸二升，水五升，煮取三升，以绵染拭发根。 《圣惠方》：治头风痛，每欲天阴雨风先发者。 用桂心一两，为末，以酒调如膏，用傅顶上并额角。 陈藏器《拾遗·序》云：头疼欲死，鼻内吹消石末愈。 日华子云：治头痛，水调决明子，贴太阳穴。 又方，决明子作枕，胜黑豆，治头风，明目也。 《外台秘要》：治头疼欲裂，当归二两，酒一升，煮取六合，饮至再服。 《孙兆口诀》云：治头痛。 附子炮、石膏煅等分，为末，入脑、麝少许，茶酒下半钱。 《斗门方》：治卒头痛，白僵蚕碾为末，去丝，以熟水二钱匕，立差。 又方，治偏头痛，用京芎细锉，酒浸服之，佳。 《博济方》：治偏头疼，至灵散，雄黄、细辛等分，研令细，每用一字已下，左边疼吹入右鼻，右边疼吹入左鼻，立效。 《经验后方》：治偏头疼绝妙，荜拨为末，令患者口中含温水，左边疼，令左鼻吸一字，右边疼，令右鼻吸一字，效。 《集验方》：治偏正头疼，谷精草一两，为末，用白面调，摊纸花子上，贴疼处，乾又换。 偏头疼方，用生萝卜汁一蚬壳，仰卧，注鼻，左痛注左，右痛注右，左右俱注亦得，神效。 《外台秘要》：头风白屑如麸糠方。 坚截楮木作枕，六十日一易新者。 治卒风喑不得语方第二十 治卒不得语方，以苦酒煮瓜子，薄颈一周，以衣苞，一日一夕乃解，即差。 又方，煮大豆煎其汁，令如饴，含之。 亦但浓煮，饮之。 又方，煮豉汁，稍服之一日，可美酒半升中搅，分三服。 又方，用新好桂，削去皮，捣筛，三指撮，着舌下，咽之。 又方，锉谷枝叶，酒煮热灰中，沫出，随多少饮之。 治卒失声，声噎不出方。 橘皮五两，水三升，煮取一升，去滓，顿服，倾合服之。 又方，浓煮苦竹叶，服之差。 又方，捣蘘荷根，酒和绞，饮其汁。 此本在杂治中。 又方，通草、乾姜、附子、茯神各半两，防风、桂、石膏各二两，麻黄一两半，白朮半两，杏人三十枚，十物捣筛，为末，蜜丸如大豆大，一服七丸，渐增加之，凡此皆中风。 又有竹沥诸汤甚多，此用药虽少，而是将治所患，一剂不差，更应服之。 又方，针大槌旁一寸五分，又刺其下停针之。 又方，矾石、桂，末，绵裹如枣，内舌下，有唾出之。 又方，烧马勒衔铁令赤，内一升苦酒中，破一鸡子，合和饮之。 若卒中冷，声嘶哑者，甘草一两，桂二两，五味子二两，杏人三十枚，生姜八两，切，以水七升，煮取二升，为二服，服之。
chunks.translated_text:
From *Imperial Grace Formulary*: For white patches, burn snake slough into powder, mix with vinegar, and apply—excellent.

Another formula: For wind-stroke with vexing heat and itchy skin sores, use four liang of *tigho* (clarified butter). Take one #36 spoonful mixed with wine per dose.

From *Collected Verified Formulas*: For wind qi lodged in the skin causing unceasing itch.
Grill wasp nests and mix equal parts with cicada slough, grind into powder, and take one *qianbi* with wine, two or three times daily.

Another formula: Equal parts cicada slough and *bohe* (mint), grind into powder, and take one *qianbi* with wine, three times daily.

*Miscellaneous Records of the Northern Dream* states: A court official consulted Physician Liang, who diagnosed him: "Your wind illness is severe; return home at once." The official then saw Zhao E, a veterinarian from Fuzhou, who examined him and likewise declared the illness critical. "There is but one method," he said. "Try eating crisp pears—any quantity, chewed or juiced. After ten days at home consuming only crisp pears, he recovered fully."

From *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*: For head wind and headache, stir-fry three *sheng* of soybeans until silent, then place in a twelve-*sheng* jar with nine *sheng* of clear wine. While the beans are still hot, add them to the wine, seal with honeyed mud for seven days, then take warm.

Master Sun’s formula for head wind pain: Wash the head with fermented soybean decoction and avoid wind—immediate relief.

From *Supplement to Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*: For head wind, pound *tinglizi* (pepperweed seeds), steep in hot water, strain the juice, and wash the head.

Another formula for head wind and hair washing: Boil two *sheng* of *wuzhuyu* (evodia fruit) in five *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*, then soak cotton and wipe the hair roots.

From *Imperial Grace Formulary*: For head wind pain that flares before windy or rainy weather.
Grind one *liang* of *guixin* (cassia heart) into powder, mix with wine into a paste, and apply to the crown and temples.

Chen Cangqi’s *Supplement to Materia Medica* states: For unbearable headache, blow *xiaoshi* (saltpeter) powder into the nostrils—immediate cure.

*Rihuazi* states: For headache, mix *juemingzi* (cassia tora seeds) with water and apply to the temples.

Another formula: Make a pillow of *juemingzi*—superior to black beans—for head wind and improving vision.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For splitting headache, boil two *liang* of *danggui* (Chinese angelica) in one *sheng* of wine until six *ge* remain, and take in two doses.

From *Sun Zhao’s Oral Instructions*: For headache.
Equal parts roasted *fuzi* (aconite) and calcined *shigao* (gypsum), ground into powder, with a small amount of *nao* (borneol) and *she* (musk) added. Take half a *qian* with tea or wine.

From *Doumen Formulas*: For sudden headache, grind silk-less silkworm pupae into powder and take two *qianbi* with warm water—immediate relief.

Another formula: For one-sided headache, finely slice *jingxiong* (Sichuan lovage), steep in wine, and take—excellent.

From *Extensive Relief Formulas*: For one-sided headache, *Zhiling Powder*: Equal parts *xionghuang* (realgar) and *xixin* (asarum), ground finely. Use less than one *zi* per dose—blow into the right nostril for left-side pain, left nostril for right-side pain—immediate effect.

From *Tested Later Formulas*: For peerless one-sided headache, grind *bibo* (long pepper) into powder. Have the patient hold warm water in the mouth; for left-side pain, inhale one *zi* through the left nostril; for right-side pain, inhale through the right—effective.

From *Collected Verified Formulas*: For one-sided or general headache, grind one *liang* of *gujingcao* (pipewort) into powder, mix with white flour, spread on paper, and apply to the painful area. Replace when dry.

Another formula for one-sided headache: Use one *xieke* (clam shell) of fresh radish juice. Lie supine and drip into the nostril—left pain, left nostril; right pain, right nostril; both sides, both nostrils—divinely effective.

From *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*: For head wind with bran-like white scales.
Carve a firm *chumu* (paper mulberry) wood pillow and replace every sixty days.

**Chapter Twenty: Formulas for Sudden Wind-Induced Aphonia and Inability to Speak**

For sudden loss of speech: Boil melon seeds in vinegar, wrap the neck for a full day and night—relief.

Another formula: Boil soybeans, reduce the juice to a syrup, and hold in the mouth. Or simply boil thickly and drink.

Another formula: Boil *chi* (fermented soybeans) juice and take gradually. Stir half a *sheng* of fine wine into the juice and divide into three doses.

Another formula: Peel fresh, high-quality *gui* (cassia), grind, and take three pinches under the tongue, swallowing the juice.

Another formula: Chop *gu* (millet) branches and leaves, boil in wine, strain the foam, and drink as needed.

For sudden loss of voice with choked sound: Boil five *liang* of *jupi* (tangerine peel) in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, strain, and take all at once.

Another formula: Boil *kuzhuye* (bitter bamboo leaves) thickly and take—relief.

Another formula: Pound *ranghe* (edible canna) root, mix with wine, strain, and drink the juice. (Originally in Miscellaneous Treatments.)

Another formula: *Tongcao* (rice-paper plant pith), *ganjiang* (dried ginger), *fuzi* (aconite), *fushen* (poria with hostwood), half a *liang* each; *fangfeng* (saposhnikovia), *gui* (cassia), *shigao* (gypsum), two *liang* each; *mahuang* (ephedra), one and a half *liang*; *baizhu* (atractylodes), half a *liang*; *xingren* (apricot kernels), thirty pieces. Grind all into powder, form into honey pills the size of soybeans, and take seven pills per dose, gradually increasing. All these treat wind-stroke. Many other formulas use bamboo sap decoctions, but though this prescription is small, it targets the ailment precisely—if one dose fails, take another.

Another formula: Needle one *cun* and five *fen* beside the *dachui* point, then needle below and retain the needle.

Another formula: Grind *fanshi* (alum) and *gui* (cassia) into powder, wrap in cotton like a date, and place under the tongue to induce salivation.

Another formula: Heat a horse’s bit iron until red, quench in one *sheng* of vinegar, mix with a broken egg, and drink.

For sudden cold-induced hoarseness: One *liang* of *gancao* (licorice), two *liang* of *gui* (cassia), two *liang* of *wuweizi* (schisandra), thirty *xingren* (apricot kernels), eight *liang* of sliced fresh *jiang* (ginger). Boil in seven *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain, and take in two doses.

chunks.original_text: 附方 《经验后方》：治中风不语，独活一两，锉，酒二升，煎一升，大豆五合，炒有声，将药酒热投，盖良久，温服三合，未差再服。 又方，治中风不语，喉中如拽锯声，口中涎沫。 取藜芦一分，天南星一个，去浮皮，却脐子上陷一个坑子，内入陈醋一橡斗子，四面用火逼，令黄色，同一处捣，再研极细，用生蜜为丸，如赤豆大，每服三丸，温酒下。 《圣惠方》：治中风，以大声咽喉不利。 以蘘荷根二两，研，绞取汁，酒一大盏，相和令匀，不计时候，温服半盏。 治风毒脚弱痒满上气方第二十一 脚气之病，先起岭南，稍来江东，得之无渐，或微觉疼痹，或两胫小满，或行起忽弱，或小腹不仁，或时冷时热，皆其候也。 不即治，转上入腹。 便发气，则杀人。
chunks.translated_text:
Additional Formulas
From *Proven Later Formulas*:
For wind-stroke with loss of speech: One *liang* of *duhuo* (pubescent angelica), sliced, simmered in two *sheng* of wine until one *sheng* remains; five *ge* of soybeans, stir-fried until crackling. Pour the hot medicinal wine over the beans, cover for a long while, then take three *ge* warm. If the condition persists, take again.

Another formula for wind-stroke with loss of speech, wheezing in the throat like a saw, and foaming at the mouth:
Take one *fen* of *lilu* (black false hellebore) and one *tiannanxing* (arisaema rhizome). Remove the outer skin of the *tiannanxing* and hollow out a small pit on the navel side. Fill the pit with one *rongdou* of aged vinegar, then heat all sides over a fire until yellow. Pound together, grind to an extremely fine powder, and form into pills with raw honey the size of red beans. Take three pills each time with warm wine.

From *Sagely Benefit Formulas*:
For wind-stroke with loud voice but impaired throat:
Take two *liang* of *ranghe* root (mioga ginger), grind, and press to extract the juice. Mix with one large cup of wine, stir evenly, and take half a cup warm at any time.

Formula Twenty-One: For Wind-Toxin Leg Weakness with Fullness and Upward Qi
The disease of *jiaoqi* (leg qi) first arose in Lingnan and gradually spread to Jiangdong. It strikes without warning—sometimes with slight pain or numbness, sometimes with mild swelling in both shins, or sudden weakness upon standing, or numbness in the lower abdomen, or alternating chills and fever—all its signs. If not treated immediately, it ascends into the abdomen, then erupts as qi and kills.

chunks.original_text: 治之多用汤酒摩膏，种效#37既多，不但一剂，今只取单效，用兼灸法。 取好豉一升，三蒸三曝乾，以好酒三斗，渍#38之三宿可饮，随人多少。 欲预防，不必待时，便与酒煮豉服之。 脚弱其得小愈，及更营诸方服之，并及灸之。 次服独活酒方，独活五两，附子五两，生用，切，以酒一斗，渍经三宿，服从一合始，以微痹为度。 又方，白矾石二斤，亦可用钟乳，末，附子三两，豉三升，酒三斗，渍四五日，稍饮之。 若此有气，加苏子二升也。 又方，好硫黄三两，末之，牛乳五升，先煮乳水五升，仍内硫黄，煎取三升，一服三合。 亦可直以乳煎硫黄，不用水也。 卒无牛乳，羊乳亦得。 又方法，先煎牛乳三升，令臧半，以五合，辄服硫黄末一两，服毕，厚盖取汗，勿令得风，中问更一服，暮又一服。 若已得汗，不复更取，但好将息将护之。 若未差，愈后数日中亦可更作。 若长将亦可煎为丸。 北人服此治脚多效，但须极好硫黄耳，可预备之。 若胫已满，捏之没指者，但勒饮乌犊牛溺二三升，使小便利，息渐渐消。 当以铜器，尿取新者为佳。 无乌牛，纯黄者亦可用之。 又方，取牵牛子，捣，蜜丸，如小豆大五丸，取令#39小便利。 亦可正尔吞之。 其子黑色，正似梂子核形，市人亦卖之。 又方，三白根，捣碎，酒饮之。 又方，酒若水煮大豆，饮其汁。 又，食小豆亦佳。 又，生研胡麻，酒和服之，差。 又方，大豆三升，水一斗，煮取九升，内清酒九升，又煎取九升，稍稍饮之。 小便利，则肿歇也。 其有风引、白鸡、竹沥、独活诸汤，及八风、石斛、狗脊诸散，并别在大方中。 金芽酒最为治之要，今载其方。 蜀椒、茵芋、金牙、细辛、菵草、乾地黄、防风、附子、地肤、蒴藋、升麻各四两，人参三两，羌活一斤，牛膝五两，十四物切，以酒四斗，渍七日，饮二三合，稍加之。 亦治口不能言，脚屈，至良。 又有侧子酒，亦效。 若田舍贫家，此药可酿，拔葜及松节、松叶皆善。 拔葜净洗，锉之一斛，以水三斛，煮取九斗，以渍曲，及煮去滓，取一斛渍饭，酿之如酒法，熟即取饮，多少任意，可顿作三五斛。 若用松节、叶，亦依准此法，其汁不厌浓也。 患脚屈，积年不能行，腰脊挛痹，及腹内紧结者，服之不过三五剂，皆平复。 如无酿，水边商陆亦佳。 其灸法孔穴亦甚多，恐人不能悉皆知处，今止疏要者，必先从上始，若直灸脚，气上不泄则危矣，先灸大椎。 在项上大节高起者，灸其上面一穴耳，若气，可先灸百会五十壮，穴在头顶凹中也。 肩井各一百壮。 在两肩小近头凹处，指捏之，安令正得中穴耳。 次灸膻中五十壮。 在胸前两边对乳胸厌骨解间，指按觉气翕翕尔是也。 一云正胸中一穴也。 次灸巨阙。 在心厌尖尖四下一寸，以赤度之，凡灸以上部五穴，亦足治其气。 若能灸百会、风府#40、胃管及五藏腧，则益佳，视病之宽急耳。 诸穴出《灸经》不可具载之。 次乃灸风市百壮。 在两髀外，可平倚垂手直掩髀上，当中指头大筋上，捻之，自觉好也。 次灸三里二百壮。 以病人手横掩，下并四指，名曰一夫，指至膝头骨下指中节是其穴，附胫骨外边捻之，凹凹然也。 次灸上廉一百壮。 又灸三里下一夫。
