To treat this, decoctions, wines, massages, and ointments are commonly used. As there are many effective remedies (#37), not just one formula, here I select only those of singular efficacy, supplemented with moxibustion.

Take one *sheng* of fine fermented soybeans, steam three times and sun-dry three times. Soak in three *dou* of good wine for three nights until drinkable, adjusting the quantity to the patient’s capacity. For prevention, administer without waiting for symptoms: boil the fermented soybeans in wine and take. When leg weakness shows slight improvement, further prepare other formulas and apply moxibustion.

Next, the *Du Huo* Wine formula: five *liang* each of *du huo* (pubescent angelica) and raw, sliced *fuzi* (aconite), steeped in one *dou* of wine for three nights. Begin with one *ge* per dose, increasing until mild numbness is felt.

Another formula: two *jin* of *bai fan shi* (alunite) or *zhongru* (stalactite powder), three *liang* of *fuzi*, and three *sheng* of fermented soybeans, steeped in three *dou* of wine for four to five days. Drink gradually. If qi stagnation is present, add two *sheng* of *suzi* (perilla seed).

Another formula: grind three *liang* of fine sulfur into powder. Boil five *sheng* of cow’s milk with five *sheng* of water, add the sulfur, and reduce to three *sheng*. Take three *ge* per dose. Alternatively, boil sulfur directly in milk without water. If cow’s milk is unavailable, sheep’s milk may be used.

Another method: reduce three *sheng* of cow’s milk by half, then take five *ge* with one *liang* of sulfur powder. After ingestion, cover thickly to induce sweating, avoiding drafts. Take another dose midday and one at dusk. If sweating occurs, do not repeat; simply rest and recover. If unresolved, repeat after several days. For long-term use, it may be decocted into pills.

Northerners find this sulfur remedy highly effective for leg disorders, provided the sulfur is of the finest quality. It should be prepared in advance.

If the shins are swollen such that pressing leaves an imprint, force the patient to drink two to three *sheng* of black calf’s urine to promote urination and gradually reduce swelling. Use a copper vessel, and fresh urine is best. If no black calf is available, a pure yellow one may suffice.

Another formula: grind *qianniuzi* (morning glory seeds), mix with honey into pills the size of small beans, and take five pills to promote urination. They may also be swallowed whole. The seeds are black, resembling *qiouzi* kernels, and are sold in markets.

Another formula: crush *sanbai* root and take with wine.

Another: boil black soybeans in water or wine and drink the broth.

Another: eating small red beans is also beneficial.

Another: grind raw *huma* (sesame), mix with wine, and take to cure the condition.

Another: boil three *sheng* of black soybeans in one *dou* of water to nine *sheng*, add nine *sheng* of clear wine, and reduce again to nine *sheng*. Drink gradually; urination will relieve the swelling.

Formulas such as *Feng Yin*, *Bai Ji*, *Zhu Li*, and *Du Huo* decoctions, as well as *Ba Feng*, *Shi Hu*, and *Gou Ji* powders, are detailed in comprehensive medical texts.

*Jin Ya* Wine is most essential for treatment; its formula is recorded here: four *liang* each of *shujiao* (Sichuan pepper), *yinyu* (skimmia), *jin ya* (golden teeth), *xixin* (asarum), *wang cao* (lithospermum), *gan dihuang* (dried rehmannia), *fangfeng* (saposhnikovia), *fuzi* (aconite), *difu* (kochia), *shuodi* (glossy privet), and *shengma* (cimicifuga); three *liang* of *renshen* (ginseng); one *jin* of *qianghuo* (notopterygium); and five *liang* of *niuxi* (achyranthes). Cut the fourteen ingredients, steep in four *dou* of wine for seven days, and drink two to three *ge* per dose, gradually increasing. It also treats speechlessness and bent legs with excellent results. *Cezi* Wine is also effective.

For rural or impoverished households, these remedies may be brewed: *baqia* (smilax), pine nodes, and pine needles are all beneficial. Wash and chop one *hu* of *baqia*, boil in three *hu* of water to nine *dou*, strain, and use the liquid to soak yeast and cook rice, brewing as one would wine. When ready, drink freely, preparing three to five *hu* at once. If using pine nodes or needles, follow the same method; the liquid should be as concentrated as possible.

For those with bent legs, unable to walk for years, or suffering from lumbar and spinal contracture and abdominal tightness, three to five doses will restore health.

If brewing is impractical, *shanglu* (pokeweed) by the water’s edge is also effective.

Moxibustion points are numerous, but as not all may be known, I record only the essentials. Begin from the upper body; moxibustion on the legs alone risks trapping qi and causing danger.

First, moxa *Dazhui*: the prominent vertebra at the nape. Apply moxa to the point above it. If qi stagnation is present, first moxa *Baihui* with fifty cones—this point lies in the depression atop the head.

Next, moxa *Jianjing* on both shoulders with one hundred cones each. The point lies in the depression near the head on the shoulders; press with fingers to locate the center.

Next, moxa *Danzhong* with fifty cones. This point lies between the breasts, at the junction of the sternum and ribs, where pressing elicits a subtle qi sensation. Some say it is the single point at the center of the chest.

Next, moxa *Juque*, located one *cun* below the tip of the xiphoid process, measured by the patient’s finger-width. Moxibustion at these five upper points suffices to treat qi stagnation. Moxibustion at *Baihui*, *Fengfu* (#40), *Weiguan*, and the five *zang* transport points is even better, depending on the urgency of the condition. All points are recorded in moxibustion manuals and cannot be fully listed here.

Next, moxa *Fengshi* with one hundred cones. This point lies on the outer thigh; stand upright, let the hands hang naturally, and press the thigh where the middle finger rests—this is the point, where pressing feels appropriate.

Next, moxa *Zusanli* with two hundred cones. Have the patient place their hand horizontally below the knee, fingers together (a measure called *yifu*). The point lies one *yifu* below the kneecap, at the outer edge of the shinbone, where pressing reveals a depression.

Next, moxa *Shang Lian* with one hundred cones, located one *yifu* below *Zusanli*.

The disease of *jiaoqi* (leg qi) first arose in Lingnan and gradually spread to Jiangdong. It strikes without warning—sometimes with slight pain or numbness, sometimes with mild swelling in both shins, or sudden weakness upon standing, or numbness in the lower abdomen, or alternating chills and fever—all its signs. If not treated immediately, it ascends into the abdomen, then erupts as qi and kills.

chunks.original_text: 次灸下廉一百壮。 又在上廉下一夫。 次灸绝骨二百壮。 在外踝上三寸余，指端取踝骨上际，屈指头四寸便是，与下廉颇相对，分间二穴也，此下一十八穴，并是要穴，余伏兔、犊鼻穴，凡灸此壮数，不必顿毕，三日中报灸合尽。 又方，孔公孽二斤，石斛五两，酒二斗浸，服之。 附方 《斗门方》：治卒风毒，肿气急痛，以柳白皮一斤，锉，以酒煮令热，帛裹熨肿上，冷再煮，易之，甚妙也。 《圣惠方》：治走注风毒疼痛，用小芥子，末，和鸡子白调傅之。 《经验后方》：治风毒骨髓疼痛，芍药二分，虎骨一两，炙，为末，夹绢袋贮，酒三升，渍五日，每服二合，日三服。 《食医心镜》：除一切风湿痹，四肢拘孪。 苍耳子三两，捣末，以水一升半，煎取七合，去滓，呷之。 又，治筋脉拘挛，久风湿痹，下气，除骨中邪气，利肠胃，消水肿，久服轻身益气力。 薏苡人一升，捣，为散，每服以水二升，煮两匙末，作粥，空腹食。 又主#41补虚，去风湿痹，醍醐二大两，暖酒一杯，和醍醐一匙饮之。 《经验方》：治诸处皮裹面痛，何首乌，末，姜汁调成膏，痛处以帛子裹之，用火炙鞋底熨之，妙。 孙真人方：主脚气及上气，取鲫鱼一赤长者，作脍，食一两顿差。 《千金翼》：治脚气冲心，白矾二两，以水一斗五升，煎三五沸，浸洗脚，良。 《广利方》：治脚气冲烦，闷乱不识人，大豆一升，水三升，浓煮取汁，顿服半升。 如未定，可更服半升，即定。 苏恭云：凡患脚气，每旦任意饱食，午后少食，日晚不食，如饥可食豉粥。 若暝不消，欲致霍乱者： 即以高良姜二两，打碎，以水三升，煮取一升，顿服尽，即消，待极饥乃食一饱#42薄粥，其药唯极饮之良。 若卒无高良姜，母姜一两代之，以清酒一升，煮令极熟，和滓食之，虽不及高良姜，亦大效矣。 唐本注云：脚气。 煮荭草浓汁渍之，多差。 《简要济众》：治脚气连腿肿满，久不差方。 黑附子一两，去皮脐，生用，捣为散，生姜汁调如膏，涂傅肿上，药乾再调涂之，肿消为度。 治服散卒发动困#43笃方第二十二 凡服五石护命更生及锺乳寒食之散，失将和节度，皆致发动其病，无所不为，若发起仓卒，不以渐而至者，皆是散势也，宜及时救解之，若四肢身外有诸一切痛违常者。 皆即冷水洗数百遍，热有所冲，水渍布巾，随以拓之。 又水渍冷石以熨之，行饮暖酒，逍遥起行。 若心腹内有诸一切疾痛违常，烦闷惛恍者，急解之，取冷，热取温酒饮一二升，渐渐稍进，觉小宽更进冷食，其心痛者，最急，若肉冷，口已噤，但折齿下热酒差。 若腹内有结坚热癖使众疾者，急下之。 栀子十四枚，豉五合，水二升，煮取一升，顿服之。 热甚已发疮者，加黄芩二两。 癖食犹不消，恶食畏冷者更下。 好大黄末半升，芒消半升，甘草二两，半夏、黄芩、芫花各一分，捣为散，藏密器中。 欲服，以水八升，煮大枣二十枚，使烂，取四升，去枣，乃内药五方寸匕搅和，着火上，三上三下，毕，分三服，旦一服便利者，亦可停。 若不快，更一服。 下后即作酒粥，食二升，次作水飧进之，不可不即食，胃中空虚，得热入，便煞人矣。 得下后应长将备急大黄、葶苈、豉各一合，杏人、巴豆三十枚，捣，蜜丸如胡豆大，日服二枚。

**Alternative Formula:**
Steep two *jin* of *Konggongnie* and five *liang* of *shihu* in two *dou* of wine, then consume.

**Appended Formulas:**

*From the* **Doumen Fang***:*
To treat sudden wind-toxin, swelling, tightness, and acute pain: Take one *jin* of willow bark, chop it, and boil it in wine until hot. Wrap it in silk and apply it to the swollen area. When it cools, reheat and replace it. This method is highly effective.

*From the* **Shenghui Fang***:*
To treat migratory wind-toxin pain: Grind small mustard seeds into powder, mix with egg white, and apply as a poultice.

*From the* **Jingyan Hou Fang***:*
To treat wind-toxin bone-marrow pain: Grind two *fen* of *shaoyao* and one *liang* of roasted *hugu* into powder, place in a silk pouch, and steep in three *sheng* of wine for five days. Take two *ge* per dose, three times daily.

*From the* **Shiyi Xinjing***:*
To dispel all wind-damp impediment and tetany of the limbs: Grind three *liang* of *cangerzi* into powder, decoct in one and a half *sheng* of water until seven *ge* remain, strain, and sip.

Also, to treat muscle spasms, chronic wind-damp impediment, downbearing *qi*, expelling pathogenic *qi* from the bones, harmonizing the intestines and stomach, dispersing water swelling, and—with prolonged use—lightening the body and augmenting *qi* and strength: Take one *sheng* of *yiyiren*, grind into powder, and for each dose, boil two *sheng* of water with two spoonfuls of the powder to make a congee. Consume on an empty stomach.

Also, to supplement deficiency, dispel wind-damp impediment: Warm one cup of wine, mix in two large *liang* of *tihu*, and take one spoonful of the mixture.

*From the* **Jingyan Fang***:*
To treat pain beneath the skin anywhere on the body: Grind *heshouwu* into powder, mix with ginger juice to form a paste, apply to the painful area, and wrap with silk. Then, heat the sole of a shoe over fire and press it against the area. This method is highly effective.

*From Sun Zhenren’s Formula:*
To treat *jiaoqi* and counterflow *qi*: Prepare *kuai* from one large red crucian carp and consume one or two portions at once for relief.

*From the* **Qianjin Yi***:*
To treat *jiaoqi* surging upward to the heart: Boil two *liang* of alum in one *dou* and five *sheng* of water for three to five boilings, then soak and wash the feet. This is highly effective.

*From the* **Guangli Fang***:*
To treat *jiaoqi* causing vexation, agitation, and loss of consciousness: Boil one *sheng* of soybeans in three *sheng* of water to make a thick decoction, then consume half a *sheng* at once. If symptoms persist, take another half *sheng* to stabilize the condition.

Su Gong states: For those suffering from *jiaoqi*, eat to satiety in the morning as desired, eat lightly after noon, and fast in the evening. If hungry, consume fermented soybean congee. If digestion is poor and symptoms resemble impending cholera:
Take two *liang* of *gaoliangjiang*, crush it, and boil in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Consume it all at once to resolve the condition. Wait until extremely hungry, then eat a full portion of thin congee. This remedy is most effective when taken in large quantities. If *gaoliangjiang* is unavailable, substitute one *liang* of ginger, boil it thoroughly in one *sheng* of clear wine, and consume it with the dregs. Though not as effective as *gaoliangjiang*, it still yields significant results.

The *Tang Bencao* notes: For *jiaoqi*, soak the affected area in a thick decoction of *hongcao* for prolonged relief.

*From the* **Jianyao Jizhong***:*
To treat *jiaoqi* with persistent leg swelling: Take one *liang* of black *fuzi*, remove the skin and navel, grind into powder, and mix with fresh ginger juice to form a paste. Apply to the swollen area, and when the paste dries, reapply with fresh mixture until the swelling subsides.

**Chapter Twenty-Two: Formulas for Acute Onset of *Fu San* Toxicity**

When consuming Five Minerals *Huming Gengsheng* or *Zhongru* Cold-Food Powder, improper regulation or dosage may provoke acute onset of illness, manifesting in myriad ways. If symptoms arise suddenly rather than gradually, they are due to the potency of the powder. Immediate intervention is required. For all external pains or abnormalities in the limbs or body, wash the affected area with cold water hundreds of times. If heat surges, soak a cloth in water and apply it as a compress. Alternatively, soak a cold stone in water and use it to press the area. Drink warm wine and walk leisurely.

For all internal pains or abnormalities in the heart and abdomen—such as vexation, oppression, or confusion—act swiftly. If cold, drink warm wine in one or two *sheng* increments, gradually increasing the amount. If slight relief is felt, consume more cold food. Heart pain is most urgent; if the flesh is cold and the mouth is clenched, force open the teeth and administer hot wine for relief.

For abdominal masses, heat accumulations, or other complex conditions, purge immediately. Boil fourteen *zhizi* and five *ge* of *chi* in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, then consume it all at once. If heat is severe and sores have erupted, add two *liang* of *huangqin*. If accumulations persist and appetite is poor with aversion to cold, purge again. Prepare the following powder: half a *sheng* of fine *dahuang* powder, half a *sheng* of *mangxiao*, two *liang* of *gancao*, and one *fen* each of *banxia*, *huangqin*, and *yuanhua*. Grind into powder and store in an airtight container. To administer, boil twenty *dazao* in eight *sheng* of water until soft, then strain to obtain four *sheng* of liquid. Add five *fangcunbi* of the powder, stir well, and heat the mixture three times (raising and lowering it over the fire). Divide into three doses and consume one in the morning. If bowel movements occur, the remaining doses may be omitted. If relief is not felt, take another dose.

After purging, prepare wine congee and consume two *sheng*, followed by watery gruel. Do not delay eating, as an empty stomach may allow heat to enter, which can be fatal.

After purging, always keep the following emergency formula on hand: one *ge* each of *dahuang* and *tingli*, thirty *xingren* and *badou*, ground and mixed with honey into pills the size of *hudou*. Take two pills daily.

There are many formulas for decoctions, powders, pills, and medicinal wines, but the key lies in maintaining coolness and allowing frequent bowel movements—only seeking free flow. Additionally, one should avoid hot foods and drinks, heavy clothing, approaching fire, braving summer heat on long journeys, or excessive exposure to wind and cold.

chunks.original_text: 《圣惠方》：治乳石发动壅热，心闷吐血。 以生刺蓟捣取汁，每服三合，入蜜少许，搅匀服之。 《食疗》云：若丹石热发。 菰根和鲫鱼煮作羹食之，三两顿即便差耳。 治卒上气咳嗽方第二十三 治卒上气鸣息便欲绝方。 捣韭绞汁，饮一升许，立愈。 又方，细切桑根白皮三升，生姜三两，吴茱萸半升，水七升，酒五升，煮三沸，去滓，尽服之。 一升入口，则气下。 千金不传方。 又方，茱萸二升，生姜三两，以水七升，煮取二升，分为三服。 又方，麻黄四两，桂、甘草各二两，杏人五十枚，熬之，捣为散，温汤服方寸匕，日三。 又方，末人参，服方寸匕，日五六。 气嗽不问多少时者，服之便差方。 陈橘皮、桂心、杏人去尖皮熬，三物等分，捣，蜜丸，每服饭后须茶汤下二十丸，忌生葱。 史侍郎传。 治卒厥逆上气，又两心胁下痛满淹淹欲绝方，温汤令灼灼尔，以渍两足及两手，数易之也。 此谓奔豚病，从卒惊怖忧追得之，气下纵纵，冲心胸脐间，筑筑发动，有时不治，煞人。 诸方用药皆多，又必须煞豚，唯有一汤，但可办耳。 甘草二两，人参二两，桂心二两，茱萸一升，生姜一斤，半夏一升，以水一斗，煮取三升，分三服。 此药宜预蓄，得病便急合之。 又方，麻黄二两，杏人一两，熬令黄，捣散，酒服方寸匕，数服之，差。 治卒乏气，气不复，报肩息方。 乾姜三两，□咀，以酒一升渍之，每服三合，日三服。 又方，度手拇指折度心下，灸三壮，差。 又方，麻黄三两，先煎去沫，甘草二两，以水三升，煮取一升半，分三服。 差后，欲令不发者，取此二物，并熬杏人五十枚，蜜丸，服如桐子大四五丸，日三服，差。 又方，麻黄二两，桂、甘草各一两，杏人四十枚，以水六升，煮取二升，分三服。 此三方，并各小投杯汤，有气疹者，亦可以药捣作散，长将服之。 多冷者，加乾姜三两。 多痰者，加半夏三两。 治大走马及奔趁喘乏，便饮冷水，因得上气发热方。 用竹叶三斤，橘皮三两，以水一斗，煮取三升，去滓，分为三服，三日一剂，良。 治大热行极，及食热饼，竟饮冷水过多，冲咽不即消，仍以发气，呼吸喘息方。 大黄、乾姜、巴豆等分，末，服半钱匕，若得吐下，即愈。 若犹觉停滞在心胸膈中不利者。 瓜蒂二分，杜衡三分，人参一分，捣筛，以汤服一钱匕，日二三服，效。 治肺痿咳嗽，吐涎沫，心中温温，烟#44燥而不渴者。 生姜五两，人参二两，甘草二两，大枣十一枚，水三升，煮取一升半，分为再服。 又方，甘草二两，以水三升，煮取一升半，分再服。 又方，生天门冬，捣取汁一斗，酒一斗，饴一升，紫苑四合，铜器於汤上煎，可丸，服如杏子大一丸，日可三服。 又方，甘草二两，乾姜三两，枣十二枚，水三升，煮取一升半，分为再服。 卒得寒冷上气方。 乾苏叶三两，陈橘皮四两，酒四升，煮取一升半，分为再服。 治卒得咳嗽方。 用釜月下土一分，豉七分，捣，为丸梧子大，服十四丸。 又方，乌鸡一头，治如食法，以好酒渍之半日，出鸡，服酒。 一云苦酒一斗，煮白鸡，取三升，分三服，食鸡肉，莫与盐食，则良。 又方，从大椎下第五节下、六节上空间，灸一处，随年。 并治上气。

Pound leeks to extract their juice and drink one *sheng*; an immediate cure will follow.

Two *sheng* of *zanthoxylum* and three *liang* of fresh ginger, boiled in seven *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng*; divide into three doses.

Four *liang* of *ephedra*, two *liang* each of cinnamon and licorice, and fifty apricot kernels—roast, pound into powder, and take one square *cun* spoonful with warm water, three times daily.

Equal parts aged tangerine peel, cinnamon bark, and apricot kernels (tips and skins removed, roasted)—pound and form into honey pills. Take twenty pills after meals with tea, avoiding raw scallions. *Transmitted by Attendant Secretary Shi.*

Two *liang* of *ephedra* and one *liang* of apricot kernels—roast until yellow, pound into powder, and take one square *cun* spoonful with wine, several times daily, until cured.

Three *liang* of dried ginger—crush, steep in one *sheng* of wine, and take three *ge* per dose, three times daily.

**Another formula:**
Measure the length from the base of the thumb to the crease at the heart, then moxa three cones at this point for a cure.

**Another formula:**
Three *liang* of *ephedra*—first decoct to remove froth—with two *liang* of licorice, boiled in three *sheng* of water to yield one and a half *sheng*, divided into three doses.

Equal parts rhubarb, dried ginger, and croton seeds—grind into powder and take half a *qian* spoonful. If vomiting or diarrhea occurs, recovery will follow. If stagnation persists in the heart, chest, or diaphragm, causing discomfort:

Five *liang* of fresh ginger, two *liang* each of ginseng and licorice, and eleven jujubes—boil in three *sheng* of water to yield one and a half *sheng*, divided into two doses.

**Another formula:**
Two *liang* of licorice—boil in three *sheng* of water to yield one and a half *sheng*, divided into two doses.

Pound fresh *asparagus* to extract one *dou* of juice, mix with one *dou* of wine, one *sheng* of malt sugar, and four *ge* of *aster*—simmer in a copper vessel over a water bath until it can be formed into pills. Take one pill the size of an apricot kernel, three times daily.

Two *liang* of licorice, three *liang* of dried ginger, and twelve jujubes—boil in three *sheng* of water to yield one and a half *sheng*, divided into two doses.

Three *liang* of dried perilla leaves and four *liang* of aged tangerine peel—boil in four *sheng* of wine to yield one and a half *sheng*, divided into two doses.

One part soot from beneath a cauldron and seven parts fermented soybeans—pound into pills the size of *wu* seeds and take fourteen pills.

Prepare a black chicken as for eating, steep in good wine for half a day, then remove the chicken and drink the wine. *Alternatively, boil a white chicken in one* dou *of vinegar to yield three* sheng*, divided into three doses. Eat the chicken meat, but avoid salt for best results.*

**Another formula:**
Moxa one point between the fifth and sixth vertebrae below the *dazhui* (GV-14) point, once for each year of age. *Also treats upward qi.*

Place a live tortoise in a pit and urinate on it until submerged. After the tortoise dies, leave it for three days, then remove and burn to ash. Mix the ash with one *sheng* of fine wine to form a dry meal. Consume all at once, and shortly afterward, a large vomit will expel the cough sac, effecting a cure. Children may take half a *sheng*.

**Another formula:**
Prepare three live tortoises as for eating, remove the intestines, and boil in five *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng*. Use this liquid to steep yeast and ferment four *sheng* of glutinous rice as usual. Drink two *sheng* to finish the batch. This will permanently resolve the condition.

**Another formula:**
Remove the head of a bat, burn until charred, grind into powder, and take with a drink.

---

**Attached Formulas**

**Sun Zhenren’s Formula for Cough:**
Burn *zao jia*, grind into powder, and take two *qianbi* with fermented soybean broth.

**Ten Complete Salvation Formulas for Cough:**
Take one large *tian nan xing* (*Arisaema*), roast until cracked, and grind into powder. For each dose, take one large *qian*, boil in one *zhan* of water with three slices of fresh ginger until reduced to five *fen*, and take warm on an empty stomach at midday and before bedtime.

**Qie Zhong Fang’s Cough-Soothing Lozenge:**
Take one *liang* of *ting li* seeds from Caozhou, roast on paper until black. Add one *liang* each of *zhi mu* (*Anemarrhena*) and *bei mu* (*Fritillaria*). Grind together, then mix with half a *liang* of jujube pulp and one and a half *liang* of melted rock sugar. Form into pills the size of bullets. For each dose, wrap one pill in fresh silk and hold in the mouth, slowly swallowing the saliva. Severe cases require no more than three pills. *Modern physicians also frequently use this formula.*

**Cui Zhiti’s Fumigation Method for Chronic Cough:**
Each morning, take a portion of *kuan dong hua* (*Tussilago*) the size of a chicken egg, mix with a little honey to moisten, and place in a one-*sheng* iron pot. Use a clay bowl with a drilled hole, inserting a small bamboo tube (a brush handle will suffice). The tube should be slightly long, and the bowl and pot should fit snugly. Seal the joint with mud to prevent air leaks. Place charcoal beneath the pot. After a short time, smoke from the *kuan dong hua* will emerge from the tube. Hold the tube in the mouth and inhale the smoke, swallowing it. If chest discomfort arises, lift the head and pinch the tube to prevent smoke leakage. Inhale until the smoke is exhausted. Perform this once every five days. On the sixth day, eat a full meal of mutton noodles, and the condition will resolve permanently.

**Sheng Jin Fang’s Golden Millet Pill for Chronic, Sudden, or Consumptive Cough:**
Grind one *liang* of *ci huang* (*orpiment*) finely. Use paper-mud to seal a small box, ensuring the mud is not too thick, and let dry. Place the powdered *ci huang* inside, seal the box with water-mixed *chi shi zhi* (*halloysite*), and apply an additional layer of mud. Once dry, place the box on the ground and surround it with charcoal the size of *tanzi* bullets to form a mound. Ignite the charcoal from above, using a flatiron to cover the top, and let the fire gradually intensify. When one-third of the charcoal has burned, check if the *tanzi* pieces are uniformly red. If so, remove the fire and let cool. Open the box to retrieve the medicine, which should resemble a mirror’s surface—bright and red. Grind finely in a mortar, then mix with a water-soaked *bing* cake center to form pills the size of millet grains. Take three to five pills with licorice water, then rest for a while. *Excellent.*

chunks.original_text: 《崔元亮海上方》：疗嗽单验方。 取好梨去核，捣取汁一茶碗，着椒四十粒，煎一沸，去滓，即内黑饧一大两，消讫，细细含咽，立定。 孟诜云：卒咳嗽。 以梨一颗，刺作五十孔，每孔内以椒一粒，以面裹，於热火灰中煨令熟，出停冷，去椒食之。 又方，梨一颗去核，内酥、蜜，面裹烧令熟，食之。 又方，取梨肉内酥中煎，停冷食之。 又方，捣梨汁一升，酥一两，蜜一两，地黄汁一升，缓火煎，细细含咽。 凡治嗽皆须待冷，喘息定后方食，热食之反伤矣，冷嗽更极不可救，如此者，可作羊肉汤饼饱食之，便卧少时。 《千金方》：治小儿大人咳逆上气。 杏人三升，去皮尖，炒令黄，杵如膏，蜜一升，分为三分，内杏人，杵令得所，更内一分，杵如膏，又内一分，杵熟止，先食含之，咽汁。 《杨氏产乳》：疗上气急满，坐卧不得方。 鳖甲一大两，炙令黄，细捣为散，取灯心一握，水二升，煎取五合，食前服一钱匕，食后蜜水服一钱匕。 刘禹锡《传信方》：李亚治一切嗽及上气者。 用乾姜须是台州至好者，皂荚炮去皮子，取肥大无孔者，桂心紫色辛辣者，削去皮，三物并别捣，下筛了，各称等分，多少任意，和合后更捣筛一遍，炼白蜜和搜，又捣一二十杵，每饮服三丸，丸稍加大，如梧子，不限食之先后，嗽发即服，日三五服，噤食葱、油、咸、腥、热面，其效如神。 刘在淮南与李同幕府，李每与人药而不出方，或讥其吝，李乃情话曰：凡人患嗽，多进冷药，若见此方用药热燥，即不肯服，故但出药多效。 试之，信之。 《简要济众》：治肺气喘嗽。 马兜零二两，只用里面子，去却壳，酥半两，入碗内，拌和匀，慢火炒乾，甘草一两，炙，二味为末，每服一钱，水一盏，煎六分，温呷。 或以药末含咽津，亦得。 治痰嗽喘急不定。 桔梗一两半，捣罗为散，用童子小便半升，煎取四合，去滓，温#46服。 杨文蔚治痰嗽利胸膈方。 栝楼肥实大者，割开#47子净洗，搥破刮皮，细切，焙乾，半夏四十九个，汤洗十遍，槌破，焙，捣罗为末，用洗栝楼熟水并瓤，同熬成膏，研细为丸，如梧子大，生姜汤下二十丸。 《深师方》：疗久咳逆上气，体肿短气胀满，昼夜倚壁不得外，常作水鸡声者，白前汤主之。 白前二#48两，紫苑、半夏洗各三两，大戟七合，切，四物以水一斗，渍一宿，明日煮取三升，分三服。 禁食羊肉、饧，大佳。 《梅师方》：治久患□呷咳嗽，喉中作声不得眠。 取白前捣为末，温酒调二钱匕服。 又方，治上气咳嗽，呷呀息气，喉中作声唾黏。 以蓝实叶水浸良久，捣绞取汁一升，空腹顿服，须臾，以杏人研取汁，煮粥食之，一两日将息，依前法更服，吐痰尽方差。 《兵部手集》：治小儿大人咳逆短气，胸中吸吸，咳出涕唾，嗽出臭脓涕枯。 淡竹沥一合，日三五服，大人一升。 《圣惠方》：治伤中筋脉，急上气咳嗽。 用枣二十枚，去核，以酥四两，微火煎，入枣肉中滴尽酥，常含一枚，微微咽之。 《经验后方》：定喘化涎。 猪蹄甲四十九个，争洗控乾，每个指甲内半夏、白矾各一字，入罐子内，封闭勿令烟出，火缎通赤，去火，细研，入麝香一钱匕，人有上喘咳，用糯米饮下，小儿半钱，至妙。

**Cui Yuanliang’s *Remedies from the Sea*:**

A singularly effective formula for coughs: Take a fine pear, remove its core, and pound to extract one teacup of juice. Add forty Sichuan peppercorns, bring to a single boil, then strain. Immediately add one large *liang* of black maltose, dissolve completely, and slowly hold in the mouth to swallow. It will take effect at once.

Meng Shen states: For sudden coughing, take one pear and pierce fifty holes in it. Insert one Sichuan peppercorn into each hole, wrap in dough, and roast in hot ashes until done. Allow to cool, remove the peppercorns, and eat the pear.

Another formula: Remove the core of a pear, fill with *su* (ghee) and honey, wrap in dough, and roast until done. Eat.

Another formula: Stew pear flesh in *su* until tender, allow to cool, and eat.

Another formula: Pound one *sheng* of pear juice, one *liang* of *su*, one *liang* of honey, and one *sheng* of rehmannia juice. Simmer over a gentle fire and slowly hold in the mouth to swallow.

For all cough treatments, wait until the breathing has settled before eating, as consuming while hot will cause harm. Those with cold-induced coughs are beyond remedy. In such cases, prepare a mutton broth with noodles, eat to satiety, then lie down briefly.

**From the *Qianjin Fang*:**
To treat coughing with counterflow *qi* in children and adults: Take three *sheng* of apricot kernels, remove skins and tips, and stir-fry until yellow. Pound into a paste, add one *sheng* of honey, and divide into three portions. Mix one portion with the apricot kernels, pound to the proper consistency, then add the next portion, and pound again until smooth. Finally, add the last portion and pound thoroughly. Take before meals, holding in the mouth to swallow the juice.

**From *Yang’s Obstetrics and Pediatrics*:**
A formula for urgent fullness in the chest, making it difficult to sit or lie down: Take one large *liang* of turtle shell, roast until yellow, and grind finely into powder. Steep one handful of *dengxin* (rush pith) in two *sheng* of water, decoct to five *ge*, and take one *qianbi* before meals. After meals, take one *qianbi* with honey water.

**From Liu Yuxi’s *Transmitted Reliable Formulas*:**
Li Ya’s remedy for all coughs and counterflow *qi*: Use dried ginger—only the finest from Taizhou—along with *zaojia* (Chinese honey locust), roasted and peeled, selecting plump, unperforated pods. Also use *guixin* (cassia bark), choosing the purple, pungent variety, peeled. Pound each ingredient separately, sift, then weigh equal parts (quantity as desired). Combine, pound and sift again, then blend with refined white honey. Pound twenty to thirty times. Take three pills per dose, slightly larger than *wutong* seeds. Take whenever coughing occurs, three to five times daily, without regard to meals. Avoid onions, oil, salt, fish, and hot wheat noodles. The effect is divine.

Liu was in Huainan on the same staff as Li. Li often dispensed medicine without revealing the formula. When criticized for stinginess, Li explained: “Most people with coughs take cold medicines. If they saw this formula’s hot, drying ingredients, they would refuse to take it. That is why I only provide the medicine, and it proves effective.” Trials confirmed its reliability.

**From *Concise and Effective Remedies for the Multitudes*:**
To treat lung *qi* panting and coughing: Take two *liang* of *madouling* (birthwort fruit), using only the inner seeds and discarding the husk. Add half a *liang* of *su*, mix well in a bowl, and stir-fry over a slow fire until dry. Add one *liang* of roasted licorice, grind both into powder, and take one *qian* per dose. Decoct in one cup of water to six *fen*, and sip warm. Alternatively, hold the powder in the mouth and swallow the saliva.

For phlegm-induced coughing with urgent panting: Take one and a half *liang* of *jiegeng* (platycodon root), grind into powder, and decoct in half a *sheng* of boys’ urine to four *ge*. Strain and take warm.

Yang Wenwei’s formula for phlegm-induced coughing and chest congestion: Select a large, plump *guālóu* (trichosanthes fruit), cut open, clean the seeds, crush, and scrape the peel. Slice finely and dry by baking. Take forty-nine *banxia* (pinellia rhizomes), wash ten times in hot water, crush, and dry by baking. Grind into powder, then simmer with the *guālóu* pulp and water used to wash it until it forms a paste. Grind finely into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take twenty pills with ginger decoction.

**From the *Master Shen’s Formulas*:**
For chronic cough with counterflow *qi*, bodily swelling, shortness of breath, fullness, inability to lie flat, and constant frog-like croaking: *Baiqian* decoction governs this. Take two *liang* of *baiqian* (willowleaf swallowwort rhizome), three *liang* each of *ziwan* (tatarian aster root) and washed *banxia*, and seven *ge* of *daji* (euphorbia root). Slice, steep in one *dou* of water overnight, then decoct the next day to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses. Avoid mutton and maltose for best results.

**From *Master Mei’s Formulas*:**
For chronic *xiā* coughing with wheezing and sleeplessness: Grind *baiqian* into powder and take two *qianbi* with warm wine.

Another formula for counterflow *qi* coughing with wheezing, gasping, and sticky phlegm: Soak indigo leaves in water for a long time, pound, and extract one *sheng* of juice. Take on an empty stomach in one dose. Shortly after, grind apricot kernels to extract juice and cook porridge to eat. Rest for one or two days, then repeat the treatment until phlegm is fully expelled.

**From the *Military Ministry’s Handbook*:**
For coughing with counterflow *qi*, shortness of breath, and chest rattling in children and adults, with coughing up of foul, purulent phlegm: Take one *ge* of *danzhuli* (bamboo sap) three to five times daily. Adults may take one *sheng*.

**From the *Sagely Benefit Formulas*:**
To treat sinew and vessel damage with urgent counterflow *qi* and coughing: Take twenty jujubes, remove pits, and simmer in four *liang* of *su* over a low fire until the *su* is fully absorbed. Hold one jujube in the mouth at a time and swallow slowly.

**From the *Tested Later Formulas*:**
To suppress panting and dissolve phlegm: Take forty-nine pig trotter nails, wash and dry thoroughly. Place half a *zi* each of *banxia* and alum into each nail, seal in a jar to prevent smoke from escaping, and calcine until red-hot. Remove from fire, grind finely, and add one *qianbi* of musk. For those with upper panting and coughing, take with glutinous rice water. Children take half a *qian*. Most effective.

chunks.original_text: 《灵苑方》：治咳嗽上气喘急，嗽血，吐血。 人参好者，捣为末，每服三钱匕，鸡子清调之，五更初服便睡，去枕仰卧，只一服愈。 年深者，再服。 忌腥、咸、鲊、酱、面等，并勿过醉饱，将息佳。 席延尝治虚中有热，咳嗽脓血，口舌咽乾，又不可服冻药。 好黄耆四两，甘草一两，为末，每服三钱，如茶点羹粥中，亦可服。 《杜壬方》：治上焦有热，口舌咽中生疮，嗽有脓血。 桔梗一两，甘草二两，右为末，每服二钱，水一盏，煎六分，去滓，温服，食后细呷之。 亦治肺壅。 《经验方》：治咳嗽甚者，或有吐血新鲜。 桑根白皮一斤，米坩浸三宿，争刮上黄皮，锉细，入糯米四两，焙乾，一处捣为末，与服，米饮调下一两钱。 《斗门方》治肺破出血，忽嗽血不止者。 用海犀膏一大片，於火上炙令焦黄色，后以酥涂之，又炙再涂，令通透。 可碾为末用，汤化三大钱匕，放令服之．即血止。 水胶是也，大验。 《食医心镜》：主上气咳嗽，胸膈痞满气喘。 桃人三两，去皮尖，以水一升，研取汁，和粳米二合，煮粥食之。 又，治一切肺病，咳嗽脓血不止。 好酥五斤，熔三遍，停取凝，当出醍醐，咫#49一合差。 又主#50积年上气咳嗽，多痰喘促，唾脓血。 以萝卜子一合，研，煎汤，食上服之。 治卒身面肿满方第二#51十四 治卒肿满，身面皆洪大方。 大鲤一头，醇酒三升，煮之令酒乾尽，乃食之，勿用醋及盐豉他物杂也，不过三两服。 差。 又方，灸足内踝下白肉，三壮，差。 又方，大豆一斗，熟煮，洒，饮汁及食豆，不过数度必愈，小豆尤佳。 又方，取鸡子黄白#52相和，涂肿处，乾复涂之。 又方，杏叶锉，煮令浓，及热渍之。 亦可服之。 又方，车下李核中人十枚，研令熟，梗米三合，研，以水四升，煮作粥，令得二升，服之，三作加核也。 又方，大豆一升，以水五升，煮二升，去豆，内酒八升，更煮九升，分三四服，肿差后渴，慎不可多饮。 又方，黄牛溺，顿服三升，即觉减，未消更服之。 又方，章陆根一斤，刮去皮，薄切之，煮令烂，去滓，内羊肉一斤，下葱、豉、盐，如食法，随意令之，肿差后亦宜作。 此亦可常捣章陆，与米中半蒸作饼子食之。 又方，猪肾一枚，分为七脔，甘遂一分，以粉之，火炙令熟，一日一食，至四五，当觉腹胁鸣，小便利。 不尔更进，尽热到去皮食之，须尽为佳，不尔再之，勿食盐。 又方，切章陆二升，以酒三升，渍三宿，服五合至一升，日三服之。 凡此满，或是虚气，或是风冷气，或是水饮气，此方皆治之。 治肿入腹，苦满急，害饮食方。 大戟、乌翅末各二两，捣筛，蜜和丸，丸如桐子大，旦服二丸，当下渐退，更取令消，乃止之。 又方，葶苈子十两，椒目三两，囗#53苓三两，吴茱萸二两，捣，蜜和丸如桐子囗#54，服十丸，日三服。 又方，鲤鱼一头，重五斤者，以水二斗，煮取斗半，去鱼，泽漆五两，茯苓三两，桑根小皮切三升，泽泻五两，又煮取四升，分四服。 服之小便当利，渐消也。 又方，皂荚剥炙令黄，锉三升，酒一斗渍，石#55器煮令沸，服一升，日三服，尽更作。 若肿偏有所起处者。 以水和灰以涂之，燥复更涂。 又方，赤豆、麻子合捣，以傅肿上。

**From the *Divine Garden Formulas*:**
To treat coughing with urgent counterflow *qi*, panting, coughing of blood, and spitting of blood: Take high-quality ginseng, pound into powder, and administer three *qianbi* per dose, mixed with egg white. Take at the fifth watch, then lie down without a pillow, supine. A single dose often suffices; for chronic cases, take again. Avoid raw, salty, pickled, or fermented foods, soy sauce, wheat-based dishes, and overindulgence in food or drink. Convalesce well.

Xi Yan once treated deficiency with internal heat, coughing of pus and blood, and dry mouth and throat, where cold-natured medicines could not be taken. Take four *liang* of fine astragalus and one *liang* of licorice, grind into powder, and take three *qian* per dose, infused like tea or added to porridge or gruel.

**From Du Ren’s Formulas:**
To treat heat in the upper burner with sores in the mouth, tongue, and throat, and coughing of pus and blood: Take one *liang* of platycodon and two *liang* of licorice, grind into powder, and administer two *qian* per dose. Decoct in one cup of water until six-tenths remain, strain, and take warm after meals, sipping slowly. Also treats lung congestion.

**From the *Tested Formulas*:**
For severe coughing, or fresh blood in sputum: Take one *jin* of mulberry root bark, soak in a rice-washed pot for three nights, scrape off the yellow outer layer, and slice finely. Add four *liang* of glutinous rice, dry over a low fire, then grind together into powder. Take one to two *qian* per dose, mixed with rice water.

**From the *Doumen Formulas*:**
To treat lung rupture with incessant coughing of blood: Take a large piece of *hai xi* paste, roast over fire until charred yellow, then coat with *su* and roast again, repeating until fully permeated. Grind into powder, dissolve three large *qianbi* in hot water, and administer. The bleeding will cease. (This refers to *shui jiao*, highly effective.)

**From the *Heart Mirror of Dietary Medicine*:**
To address counterflow *qi*, coughing, chest and diaphragm fullness, and panting: Take three *liang* of peach kernels, remove skins and tips, grind with one *sheng* of water to extract juice, and cook with two *ge* of polished rice into congee. Consume.

Also, to treat all lung ailments with incessant coughing of pus and blood: Take five *jin* of fine *su*, melt and clarify three times, then allow to congeal. The resulting *tihu* (purest essence) will yield one *ge* per dose, which is curative.

Also, to address chronic counterflow *qi*, coughing, copious phlegm, panting, and spitting of pus and blood: Take one *ge* of radish seeds, grind, decoct in water, and take before meals.

---

**Section Fourteen: Formulas for Sudden Generalized Swelling and Fullness**

**For sudden swelling and fullness, with the entire body and face grossly enlarged:**
Take one large carp and three *sheng* of undiluted wine, simmer until the wine is fully absorbed, then consume the fish. Do not add vinegar, salt, fermented beans, or other ingredients. No more than two or three doses are needed for recovery.

Another formula: Moxibust three cones on the white flesh below the inner ankle. Effective.

Another formula: Take one *dou* of soybeans, cook thoroughly, strain, and drink the broth while eating the beans. A few doses will suffice; red beans are especially effective.

Another formula: Mix egg yolk and white, apply to swollen areas, and reapply as it dries.

Another formula: Chop apricot leaves, decoct until concentrated, and soak the affected area while hot. May also be taken internally.

**Ge Xianweng’s *Zhouhou Beiji Fang*, Volume Four**
**Chapter Twenty-Five: Remedies for Sudden Onset of Massive Abdominal Water Disease**

At the onset of water disease, swelling first appears above the eyes like the back of an old silkworm moth, with discoloration flanking the head’s vessels. The inner thighs grow cold, the shins become full, and pressing leaves an indentation. When turning the abdomen, a sound of shifting nodes is heard—these are its signs.

If left untreated, the body gradually swells, and the abdomen becomes fully distended. Pressing causes the flesh to rebound—by this stage, the disease has taken hold, though it may still be treated. Such conditions often arise from depletion following major illness, after diarrhea, in women post-childbirth, or when water intake is not promptly dispersed. The Triple Burner is afflicted, urination obstructed, and gradual accumulation binds together, eventually flowing into the channels and network vessels.

**Remedies:**

1. Take one *sheng* of *tingli* (tingli seeds), stir-fry, and pound in a mortar. Slit open a live male mandarin duck, mix its blood and head with the *tingli*, and pound ten thousand times. Form into pills the size of parasol-tree seeds, starting with five and gradually increasing to ten. Avoid salt. Regularly consume rice with adzuki beans and drink adzuki bean broth; snakehead fish is also beneficial.

2. Another formula: One *liang* each of *fangfeng* (saposhnikovia), *gancao* (licorice), and *tingli* (tingli seeds). Pound and mix with bitter wine to form pills the size of parasol-tree seeds. Take three pills, three times daily. Continue until the swelling subsides.

3. Another formula: Six *fen* of *xionghuang* (realgar), three *fen* of *shexiang* (musk), and two *fen* each of *gansui* (kan-sui), *yuanhua* (genkwa), and *renshen* (ginseng). Pound and mix with honey to form pills the size of soybeans. Take two pills, increasing to four. Recovery will follow.

Another formula: Soak two *sheng* of *tingli* seeds in five *sheng* of spring wine overnight. Take one *ge* at a time; urination will become unobstructed.

Another formula: One *liang* of *tingli* and twenty apricot kernels, stir-fried until yellow. Pound and divide into ten doses. Once urination is restored, recovery will follow immediately.

Another formula: *Hu Qia’s* "Mercury Pills," highly effective for water swelling and promoting urination. As attested by Yao.

One *sheng* each of *tingli* and *jiaomu*, six *liang* of *mangxiao*, and ten *liang* of mercury. Boil the mercury in water for three days and nights, then combine and pound sixty thousand times. Form into pills the size of soybeans. Take three daily, increasing by one pill each day up to ten, then restart from one. After recovery, consume beef and mutton to restore strength, and drink in moderation.

Another formula: Gather and finely chop a large quantity of *ke* tree bark. Boil into a thick decoction and reduce until it can be formed into pills. Take three pills the size of parasol-tree seeds, then another after a short while. Water will be expelled. Later, take three pills three times daily. This tree is also called *munu* and is used by southerners to build boats.

Another formula: Equal parts genuine *suhexiang* (storax), mercury, and white lead, mixed with honey into pills. Take two pills the size of soybeans three times daily. Water will be expelled; regulate diet and rest well. If *suhexiang* is unavailable, omit it.

After recovery, regulate intake of fluids and salty foods.

Another formula: One *sheng* of adzuki beans and one white chicken, prepared as for eating. Boil in three *dou* of water until fully cooked. Consume the solids and drink the broth, gradually finishing all.

Another formula: Take a green-headed male duck and boil in five *sheng* of water until one *sheng* of broth remains. Drink gradually until finished. Cover thickly to induce sweating; this is beneficial.

Another formula: Swallow ten egg yolks from swallows’ eggs at once.

Another formula: Roast mole crickets until fully cooked and eat ten daily.

Another formula: For cases where only the abdomen is swollen, with fluid movement and gurgling sounds, and the skin turns black—this is called *water gu*. Take ninety *badou* (croton seeds), remove skins and hearts, and sixty apricot kernels, remove skins and tips. Stir-fry until yellow, pound together, and form into pills the size of small beans. Take one pill with water as needed. Wine may also be consumed; this is beneficial.

Another formula: Finely pound *guishan* (Chinese lobelia) and extract its juice. Drink an amount the size of a chicken egg to expel water, then treat the *water gu* again. Alternatively, grind hemp seeds into juice and drink.

Another formula: Boil thirty *jin* of *cimicao* (motherwort) and three *dan* of its seeds to obtain one *dan* of liquid. Strain and further reduce over heat until it can be formed into pills. Take three to five or six pills the size of *zaojia* seeds. Water will be expelled through urination; then consume thin rice porridge for nourishment.

Another formula: One large handful of white cogon grass roots and three *sheng* of adzuki beans. Boil in three *sheng* of water until dry, remove the grass roots, and eat the beans. Water will be expelled through urination.

Another formula: Ten *jin* each of *shuweicao* (common club moss) and *mabiancao* (European verbena). Boil in one *dan* of water to obtain five *dou* of liquid. From Li Jiang’s *Bingbu Shouji Fang*: A remedy for water disease, regardless of duration or severity, even with adverse pulses. One large *liang* each of *daji* (euphorbia), *danggui* (Chinese angelica), and *jupi* (tangerine peel). Chop and boil in one large *sheng* of water to obtain seven *ge*. Consume at once; two to three *dou* of water will be expelled. Do not be alarmed by the severity; recovery will follow after no more than two doses. Avoid toxic foods for one year. After water is expelled, take again to prevent recurrence. This formula originates from Zhang Shangke.

From *Waitai Miyao*: For water qi. Peel and chop white *zhanglu* (pokeweed) roots into pieces the size of small beans, one large cupful. Boil in three *sheng* of water to obtain one *sheng*. Once thoroughly cooked, add one large cup of millet and cook into porridge. Consume on an empty stomach. If taken twice daily, excessive purging may occur; once daily ensures mild purgation. Avoid mixed foods.

Another remedy for water disease with swelling: Take one very large carp, remove the head, tail, and bones, retaining only the flesh. Boil with two *dou* of water and one large *sheng* of adzuki beans. Reduce to two *sheng* of liquid, strain through cloth, and consume at once. If unable to finish, divide into two doses, warming the second. After consumption, diarrhea will follow; recovery occurs once purging ceases.

Another formula: For sudden swelling and fullness. There was a case of sudden foot and leg swelling, gradually ascending to the knees, making walking impossible. Eventually, the head and face swelled, and the entire body became bloated and distended. Take the white pulp of a bitter gourd, shape into pieces the size of soybeans, wrap in dough, and boil briefly. Consume seven on an empty stomach. By midday, a *dou* of water will be expelled. For three days, water will continue to drain, leading to significant emaciation and recovery. Maintain dietary caution for three years.

chunks.original_text: 苦瓠须好者，无黡翳细理妍序者，不尔有毒不用。 《圣惠方》：治十种水不差垂死。 用貒肉半斤，切，粳米三合，水三升，葱、椒、姜、豉作粥食之。 又方，治十种水病，肿满喘促不得卧。 以蝼蛄五枚，乾为末，食前汤调半钱匕至一钱，小便通，效。 《食医心镜》：治十种水病不差垂死。 青头鸭一只，治如食法，细切，和米并五味； 煮令极熟作粥，空腹食之。 又方，主水气胀满浮肿，小便涩少。 白鸭一只，去毛肠洗馈，饭半升，以饭、姜、椒酿鸭腹中，缝定，如法蒸，候熟食之。 《杨氏产乳》：疗身体肿满，水气急，卧不得。 郁李人一大合，捣为末，和麦曲，搜作饼子，与吃入口，即大便通利气，便差。 《梅师方》：治水肿，坐卧不得，头面身体悉肿。 取东引花桑枝，烧灰淋汁，煮赤小豆，空心食，令饱，饥即食尽，不得吃饭。 又方，治水肿，小便涩。 黄牛尿饮一升，一日至夜小便利，差。 勿食盐。 又方，治心下有水。 白朮三两，泽泻五两，锉，以水三升，煎取一升半，分服。 《千金翼》：治小便不利，膀胱水气流滞。 以浮萍日乾，末，服方寸匕，日一二服良。 《经验方》：河东裴氏传经效，治水肿及暴肿。 葶苈三两，杵六千下，令如泥，即下汉防己末四两，取绿头鸭就药臼中截头，沥血於臼中，血尽，和鸭头更捣五千下，丸如梧桐子，患甚者，空腹白汤下十丸，稍可者五丸，频服，五日止。 此药利小便，有效如神。 《韦宙独行方》：疗水肿，从脚起，入腹则杀人。 用赤小豆一斗，煮令极烂，取汁四五升，温渍膝以下。 若以入腹，但服小豆，勿杂食，亦愈。 李绛《兵部手集方》亦着此法，曾得效。 治卒心腹症坚方第二十六 治卒暴症，腹中有物如石，痛如刺，昼夜啼呼，不治之，百日死。 方：牛膝二斤，以酒一斗渍，以密#3封於热灰火中，温令味出，服五合至一升，量力服之。 又方，用蒴藋根亦如此，尤良。 姚云：牛膝酒，神验也。 又方，多取当陆根捣蒸之，以新布藉腹上，药披着布上，勿腹上，冷复之，昼夜勿息。 又方，五月五日，葫十斤，去皮，桂一尺二寸，灶中黄土如鸭子一枚，合捣，以苦酒和涂，以布搭病，不过三，差。 又方，取橉木烧为灰，淋取汁八升，以酿一斛米，酒成服之，从半合始，不知，稍稍增至一二升，不尽一剂皆愈。 此灰入染绛，用叶中酿酒也。 橉，直忍切。 凡症坚之起，多以渐生，如有卒觉，便牢大，自难治也。 腹中症有结积，便害饮食，转羸瘦，治之多用陷冰、玉壶、八毒诸大药，今止取小易得者。 取虎杖根，勿令影临水上者，可得石余，杵熟煮汁，可丸，以秫米五六升，炊饭内，日中涂药后可饭，取差。 又方，亦可取根一升，捣千杵，酒渍之，从少起，日三服。 此酒治症，乃胜诸大药。 又方，蚕矢一石，桑柴烧灰，以水淋之五度，取生鳖长一尺者，内中煮之烂熟，去骨细擘，锉，更煎，令可丸，丸如梧子大，一服七丸，日三。 又方，射罔二两，椒三百粒，捣末，鸡子白和为丸，如大麻子，服一丸，渐至如大豆大，一丸至三丸为度。 又方，大猪心一枚，破头去血，捣末，雄黄、麝香当门子五枚，巴豆百枚，去心皮生用，心缝，以好酒於小铜器中煎之，令心没欲歇，随益尽三升，当糜烂，煎令可丸如麻子，服三丸，日三服。

The bitter gourd must be of fine quality—smooth, unblemished, with fine and orderly veins. If not, it is toxic and should not be used.

From *Sheng Hui Fang*: To treat ten types of water retention in near-death cases, use half a *jin* of badger meat, sliced, with three *ge* of polished rice, three *sheng* of water, and cook into a porridge with scallions, Sichuan pepper, ginger, and fermented soybeans; consume.

Another formula: For ten types of water disease with swelling, fullness, panting, and inability to lie down, take five mole crickets, dry and grind into powder, and take half a *qianbi* to one *qian* before meals, mixed with hot water. When urination becomes unobstructed, the treatment is effective.

From *Shi Yi Xin Jing*: To treat ten types of water disease in near-death cases, take one green-headed duck, prepare as for eating, finely chop, and cook with rice and the five flavors into a very soft porridge; consume on an empty stomach.

Another formula: For water qi distension, swelling, and scant, difficult urination, take one white duck, remove feathers and intestines, wash thoroughly, and stuff with half a *sheng* of rice, ginger, and Sichuan pepper. Sew shut, steam according to method, and consume when done.

From *Yang Shi Chan Ru*: To treat bodily swelling, water qi urgency, and inability to lie down, take one large handful of *Prunus japonica* kernels, pound into powder, mix with wheat yeast, and form into cakes. Consume, and the bowels will promptly move, relieving qi and restoring health.

From *Mei Shi Fang*: To treat water swelling with inability to sit or lie down, and swelling of the head, face, and entire body, take mulberry branches growing eastward, burn to ash, leach with water, and use the liquid to cook red adzuki beans. Consume on an empty stomach until full, then eat when hungry until all are finished; do not consume rice.

Another formula: For water swelling and scant urination, drink one *sheng* of yellow ox urine. Within a day and night, urination will become unobstructed, and recovery will follow. Do not consume salt.

Another formula: For water beneath the heart, take three *liang* of *Atractylodes macrocephala* and five *liang* of *Alisma*, slice, decoct in three *sheng* of water until reduced to one and a half *sheng*, and divide for consumption.

From *Qian Jin Yi*: To treat inhibited urination and stagnant bladder water qi, dry *Spirodela polyrhiza* in the sun, grind into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* once or twice daily; effective.

From *Jing Yan Fang*: A proven formula transmitted by the Pei family of Hedong for water swelling and sudden swelling: Pound three *liang* of *Lepidium* six thousand times until pasty, then add four *liang* of *Stephania tetrandra* powder. Take a green-headed duck, decapitate it over the mortar, allowing the blood to drip in. Once the blood is fully drained, mix in the duck’s head and pound another five thousand times. Form into pills the size of *Firmiana* seeds. For severe cases, take ten pills on an empty stomach with plain hot water; for milder cases, take five. Take frequently, stopping after five days. This medicine promotes urination with miraculous efficacy.

From *Wei Zhou Du Xing Fang*: To treat water swelling that begins in the feet and ascends to the abdomen, which is fatal, cook one *dou* of red adzuki beans until extremely soft, take four to five *sheng* of the liquid, and soak the area below the knees in the warm broth. If the swelling has entered the abdomen, consume only the adzuki beans without other foods; this will also cure. Li Jiang’s *Bing Bu Shou Ji Fang* also records this method, which has proven effective.

**Section Twenty-Six: Formulas for Sudden Abdominal Masses**

For sudden, violent masses in the abdomen resembling stone, with stabbing pain and day-and-night wailing, if left untreated, death occurs within a hundred days. Formula: Steep two *jin* of *Achyranthes* in one *dou* of wine, seal tightly in hot ashes to warm and extract the flavor. Consume from five *ge* to one *sheng*, adjusting according to strength.

Another formula: Use *Sambucus* root in the same manner; even better.

Yao notes: *Achyranthes* wine is divinely effective.

Another formula: Take a large quantity of *Phytolacca* root, steam and pound it, then spread on new cloth placed over the abdomen (not directly on the skin). Replace when cool; do not cease day or night.

Another formula: On the fifth day of the fifth month, take ten *jin* of bottle gourd (peeled), one *chi* and two *cun* of cinnamon, and a duck-egg-sized lump of yellow earth from a stove. Pound together, mix with bitter wine, and apply to the afflicted area with cloth. Recovery occurs within three applications.

Another formula: Burn *Poncirus* wood to ash, leach with water to obtain eight *sheng* of liquid, and use to brew one *hu* of rice into wine. Begin with half a *ge*, gradually increasing to one or two *sheng* if no effect is observed. All cases are cured before finishing one batch. This ash is also used in dyeing crimson; the leaves are used in brewing wine. *Poncirus* is pronounced *zhi ren*.

Generally, masses develop gradually. If suddenly noticed and already large and firm, they are difficult to treat. Abdominal masses and accumulations impair eating and lead to emaciation. Treatments often employ potent medicines like *Xian Bing*, *Yu Hu*, and the Eight Toxins. Here, only simple and accessible remedies are selected.

Take *Polygonum cuspidatum* root (avoid those whose shadow falls on water), gather over a *dan* in weight, pound thoroughly, and decoct to extract juice for making pills. Cook five to six *sheng* of glutinous rice into porridge, mix with the medicine, and consume at midday after applying the medicine. Recovery follows.

Another formula: Take one *sheng* of the root, pound a thousand times, steep in wine, and consume three times daily, starting with a small amount. This wine treats masses better than many potent medicines.

Another formula: Burn one *dan* of silkworm droppings with mulberry firewood to ash, leach with water five times, and place a one-*chi*-long live softshell turtle in the liquid to cook until thoroughly done. Remove bones, shred finely, and decoct further until pills can be formed. Take seven pills the size of *Firmiana* seeds, three times daily.

Another formula: Pound two *liang* of *Aconitum* and three hundred Sichuan peppercorns into powder, mix with egg white, and form into pills the size of hemp seeds. Begin with one pill, gradually increasing to the size of soybeans, with a maximum of three pills per dose.

Another formula: Take one large pig’s heart, cut open and remove blood, pound into powder, and add five grains of realgar, five *Shexiang* *musk* grains, and one hundred *Croton* seeds (remove hearts and skins, use raw). Sew the heart shut, place in a small copper vessel with good wine, and decoct until the heart is submerged and nearly dissolved. Add up to three *sheng* of wine as needed, decoct until the mixture can be formed into pills the size of hemp seeds. Take three pills, three times daily.

chunks.original_text: 酒尽不糜者，出捣蜜丸之，良。 又大黄末半斤，朴消三两，蜜一斤，合於汤上煎，可丸如梧子，服十丸，日三服之。 治鳖症伏在心下，手揣见头足，时时转者。 白雌鸡一双，绝食一宿，明旦膏煎饭饲之，取其矢，无问多少，於铜器中以溺和之，火上熬，可捣末，服方寸匕，日四五服，须消尽乃止，常饲鸡取矢，差毕，煞鸡单食之。 姚同。 治心下有物，大如杯，不得食者。 葶苈二两，熬之，大黄二两，泽漆四两，捣筛，蜜丸，和捣千杵，服如梧子大二丸，日三服，稍加。 其有陷#4冰赭鬼诸丸方，别在大方中。 治两胁下有气结者。 狼毒二两，旋覆花一两，附子二两，炮之，捣筛，蜜和丸，服如梧子大二丸，稍加至三丸，服之。 熨症法，铜器受二升许，贮鱼膏令深二三寸，作大火炷六七枚，燃之令膏暖，重纸覆症上，以器熨之，昼夜勿息，膏尽更益也。 又方，茱萸三升，碎之，以酒和煮，令熟布帛物裹以熨症上，冷更均番用之，症当移去，复逐熨，须臾消止。 亦可用好囗囗囗囗茱萸末，以鸡子白和射菵服之。 又方，灶中黄土一升，先捣葫熟，内上复捣，以苦酒浇令浥涓，先以涂布一面#5仍搭病上，以涂布上，乾复易之，取令消止，差。 治妇人脐下结物大如杯升，月经不通，发作往来，下痢赢瘦，此为气瘕，按之若牢强，肉症者，不可治，未者可治。 末乾漆一斤，生地黄三十斤，捣，绞取汁，火煎乾漆令可丸，食后服，如梧子大三丸，日三服，即差。 附方 《外台秘要方》：疗心腹宿症，卒得症。 取朱砂细研，搜饭令朱多，以雄鸡一只，先饿三日，后以朱饭饲之，着鸡於板上，收取粪，曝燥为末，温清酒服方寸匕至二钱，日三服，若病困者，昼夜可六服。 一鸡少，更饲一鸡，取足服之，俟愈即止。 又，疗食鱼肉等成症结在腹，并诸毒气方。 狗粪五升，烧末之，绵裹，酒五升，渍再宿，取清分十服，日再，已后日三服，使尽，随所食症结即便出矣。 《千金方》：治食鱼绘及用生肉，住胸膈不化，必成症瘕。 捣马鞭草汁饮之一升，生姜水亦得，即消#6。 又方，治肉症思肉不已，食讫复思。 白马尿三升，空心饮，当吐肉，肉不出即死。 《药性论》云：治症癖病。 鳖甲、诃梨勒皮、乾姜，末，等分为丸，空心下三十丸，再服。 宋明帝宫人患腰痛牵#7心，发则气绝，徐文伯视之日：发瘕。 以油灌之，吐物如发，引之长三尺，头已成蛇，能动摇，悬之滴尽，惟一发。 《胜金方》：治膜外气及气块方。 延胡索不限多少，为末，猪胰一具，切作块子，炙熟，蘸药末食之。 治心腹寒冷食饮积聚结癖方第二十七 治腹中冷癖，水谷瘾结，心下停痰，两胁痞满，按之鸣转，逆害饮食。 取大蟾蜍一枚，去皮及腹中物，支解之，芒消大人一升，中人七合，瘦弱人五合，以水六升，煮取四升，一服一升，一服后未得下，更一升，得下，则九日十日一作。 又方，茱萸八两，消石一升，生姜一斤，以酒五升，合煮，取四升，先服一服一升，不痛者止，勿再服之，下病后，好将养之。 又方，大黄八两，葶苈四两，并熬，芒消四两，熬令汁尽，熟捣，蜜和丸，丸如梧子大，食后服三丸，稍增五丸。 又方，狼毒三两，附子一两，旋覆花三两，捣蜜丸服，如梧子大，食前三丸，日三服。

If the wine is exhausted yet the mixture remains undissolved, remove and pound it with honey to form pills—this is effective.

Another formula: Take half a *jin* of *Rhei Radix et Rhizoma* (rhubarb) powder, three *liang* of *Natrii Sulfas* (mirabilite), and one *jin* of honey. Combine and decoct over a gentle heat until the mixture can be formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten pills, three times daily.

**For treating turtle-like accumulations lodged beneath the heart, where the head and feet can be felt by hand and shift intermittently:**
Take a pair of white hens, fast them for one night, then the next morning feed them with fried rice cooked in lard. Collect their droppings, regardless of quantity, mix with urine in a copper vessel, and heat over a fire until dry. Pound into powder and take one *fangcunbi* spoonful, four to five times daily, until the accumulation is fully resolved. Continue feeding the hens to collect droppings until recovery is complete, then slaughter and consume the hens alone.

**For treating an object beneath the heart, large as a cup, preventing food intake:**
Take two *liang* of *Descurainiae Semen* (tingli seed), stir-fried, two *liang* of *Rhei Radix et Rhizoma* (rhubarb), and four *liang* of *Euphorbiae Helioscopiae Herba* (zeqi). Pound, sift, and form into honey pills, pounding a thousand times. Take two pills the size of *wutong* seeds, three times daily, gradually increasing the dose.

Formulas for *xian*-like accumulations, *bingzhe*-ghost accumulations, and other such pills are recorded separately in the major formulas.

**For treating qi bind beneath the ribs:**
Take two *liang* of *Euphorbiae Ebracteolatae Radix* (langdu), one *liang* of *Inulae Flos* (xuanfuhua), and two *liang* of *Aconiti Radix Lateralis Praeparata* (prepared fuzi). Pound, sift, and form into honey pills. Take two pills the size of *wutong* seeds, gradually increasing to three pills.

**Moxibustion method for accumulations:**
Use a copper vessel holding about two *sheng*, fill with fish oil to a depth of two to three *cun*, and prepare six or seven large moxa cones. Ignite the cones to warm the oil, cover the accumulation with heavy paper, and apply the vessel to press and warm it. Continue day and night without pause; replenish the oil as it depletes.

Another formula: Crush three *sheng* of *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (zhuyu), mix with wine, and boil until cooked. Wrap in cloth and apply to the accumulation. Replace when cool, and continue until the accumulation shifts away. Persist in warming until it fully resolves.

Alternatively, use fine *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* powder mixed with egg white and *Aconiti Kusnezoffii Radix* (shegong) for oral intake.

Another formula: Take one *sheng* of yellow earth from a stove, pound thoroughly, then add more and pound again. Moisten with bitter wine until damp, apply to one side of a cloth, and place over the afflicted area. Replace when dry until the accumulation resolves.

**For treating women with accumulations beneath the navel, large as a cup or *sheng*, obstructing menstruation, causing intermittent pain, diarrhea, emaciation, and weakness—this is qi *jia*. If the mass feels firm and unyielding upon palpation, it is a flesh accumulation and incurable; if not, it may be treated.**
Take one *jin* of *Toxicodendri Resina* (dried lacquer) powder and thirty *jin* of fresh *Rehmanniae Radix* (dihuang). Pound the *dihuang* to extract its juice, then decoct the lacquer powder in the juice until it can be formed into pills. Take three pills the size of *wutong* seeds after meals, three times daily, until resolved.

**Additional Formulas**

From *Waitai Miyao Fang*:
**For treating chronic accumulations in the heart and abdomen, or sudden-onset accumulations:**
Grind *Cinnabaris* (zhusha) finely and mix with rice to form a red paste. Take a rooster, starve it for three days, then feed it the red rice. Secure the rooster to a board and collect its droppings. Dry in the sun, grind into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* to two *qian* spoonfuls with warm clear wine, three times daily. For severe cases, take up to six doses day and night. If one rooster’s droppings are insufficient, feed another until enough is collected. Discontinue upon recovery.

Another formula: **For treating accumulations in the abdomen from fish, meat, or other toxins:**
Burn five *sheng* of dog feces to ash, wrap in silk, and steep in five *sheng* of wine for two nights. Strain and divide into ten doses, taking two daily initially, then three daily until finished. The accumulation will be expelled according to the ingested substance.

From *Qianjin Fang*:
**For treating undigested fish or raw meat lodged in the chest and diaphragm, leading to accumulations:**
Pound *Verbenae Herba* (mabiancao) to extract one *sheng* of juice and drink. Ginger water may also be used; the accumulation will dissolve immediately.

Another formula: **For treating flesh accumulations with insatiable cravings for meat:**
Drink three *sheng* of white horse urine on an empty stomach. The patient will vomit the flesh; if it does not emerge, death will follow.

From *Yaoxing Lun*:
**For treating *zheng* and *pi* diseases:**
Grind equal parts *Trionycis Carapax* (bie jia), *Chebulae Fructus Pericarpium* (helile skin), and *Zingiberis Rhizoma* (dried ginger) into powder and form into pills. Take thirty pills on an empty stomach, twice daily.

During the reign of Emperor Ming of the Song, a palace woman suffered from lower back pain radiating to the heart, causing fainting during attacks. Xu Wenbo examined her and diagnosed a *jia* accumulation. He administered oil, inducing her to vomit a hair-like substance three *chi* long, with a head resembling a snake that writhed. It was hung up to drain completely, leaving only a single strand of hair.

From *Shengjin Fang*:
**For treating qi outside the membranes and qi masses:**
Grind *Corydalis Rhizoma* (yanhusuo) into powder without limit. Take one pig’s pancreas, cut into pieces, roast until cooked, and dip in the powder to consume.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: Formulas for Cold Accumulations, Food and Drink Stagnation, and Bindings in the Heart and Abdomen**

**For treating cold accumulations in the abdomen, food and water stagnation, phlegm retention beneath the heart, fullness and distension in the ribs, gurgling upon palpation, and counterflow harming food intake:**
Take one large toad, remove its skin and internal organs, and dismember it. Use one *sheng* of *Natrii Sulfas* (mangxiao) for adults, seven *ge* for average individuals, and five *ge* for the weak or emaciated. Add six *sheng* of water, decoct to four *sheng*, and take one *sheng* per dose. If no purgation occurs after the first dose, take another *sheng*. Once purgation occurs, administer every nine or ten days.

Another formula: Take eight *liang* of *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (zhuyu), one *sheng* of *Nitrum* (xiaoshi), and one *jin* of fresh ginger. Decoct with five *sheng* of wine to four *sheng*. Take one *sheng* per dose; if no pain occurs, discontinue. Do not take a second dose. After purgation, provide good convalescent care.

Another formula: Take eight *liang* of *Rhei Radix et Rhizoma* (dahuang) and four *liang* of *Descurainiae Semen* (tingli seed), both stir-fried, and four *liang* of *Natrii Sulfas* (mangxiao), stir-fried until dry. Pound thoroughly and form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take three pills after meals, gradually increasing to five pills.

Another formula: Take three *liang* of *Euphorbiae Ebracteolatae Radix* (langdu), one *liang* of *Aconiti Radix Lateralis Praeparata* (fuzi), and three *liang* of *Inulae Flos* (xuanfuhua). Pound, form into honey pills, and take three pills the size of *wutong* seeds before meals, three times daily.

Add up to three *sheng* of wine as needed, decoct until the mixture can be formed into pills the size of hemp seeds. Take three pills, three times daily.

Another formula: Take thirty *Crotonis Fructus* (badou), remove the kernels, and twenty *Armeniacae Semen* (xingren), stir-fry both. Add six *fen* of *Platycodonis Radix* (jiegeng), four *fen* of *Veratri Radix et Rhizoma* (lilu), and three *fen* of *Gleditsiae Fructus* (zaojia), all roasted. Pound thoroughly, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *hudou* beans. Take one pill before meals, twice daily. For purging, take two pills. With prolonged convalescent care, full recovery may be achieved in a hundred days.

Another formula: Take two *liang* of *Fritillariae Bulbus* (beimu), two *liang* of *Platycodonis Radix* (jiegeng), one *liang* of *Alumen* (fanshi), and one *liang* of *Crotonis Fructus* (badou), removing kernels and skin for raw use. Pound a thousand times, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take two pills per dose; reduce dosage slightly after recovery.

Another formula: Take one *liang* of *Poria* (fuling) and three *liang* of *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (zhuyu). Pound, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take five pills, three times daily.

Another formula for sudden retention of undigested food and lingering fluids causing abdominal distress: Take three *liang* each of *Rhei Radix et Rhizoma* (dahuang), *Poria* (fuling), and *Natrii Sulfas* (mangxiao), and one *fen* of *Crotonis Fructus* (badou). Pound, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take two pills per dose; discontinue if no pain occurs.

Another formula: Take two *liang* of *Zanthoxyli Semen* (jiaomu) and one *liang* of *Crotonis Fructus* (badou), removing skin and kernels, stir-fried. Pound and form into pills the size of *sesame seeds* with jujube paste. Take two pills; discontinue when pain subsides.

Another formula: Take one *Crotonis Fructus* (badou), remove kernel and skin, stir-fry, along with fourteen *Zanthoxyli Semen* (jiaomu) and sixteen *Sojae Semen Praeparatum* (chi). Pound together to form pills. Take two pills to induce vomiting and diarrhea. If incomplete, take two more pills. Purging with *Sishen Wan* is also effective.

*Zhonghou Hei Wan* is the foremost remedy for all accumulations, congealed phlegm, and sores. Take four *fen* each of *Platycodonis Radix* (jiegeng) and *Cinnamomi Cortex* (gui), eight *fen* of *Crotonis Fructus* (badou) with kernels and skin removed, five *fen* of *Armeniacae Semen* (xingren) with skin removed, and twelve *fen* of *Genkwa Flos* (yuanhua), all stir-fried until purplish. First pound the three ingredients into powder, then pound *Crotonis Fructus* and *Armeniacae Semen* into a paste. Combine and pound two thousand times, forming pills the size of *hudou* beans. Take one pill to induce purgation, increasing to two or three pills as needed. For infants ten days old with convulsions, administer one or two pills the size of millet grains. For any abdominal discomfort or perceived bodily distress, take immediately; one or two bouts of purgation will bring relief.

*Sulphur Pills*, extremely warming, treat severe internal cold where even in summer one cannot remove clothing. Take equal parts of *Sulphur* (liuhuang), *Alumen* (fanshi), *Zingiberis Rhizoma* (ganjiang), *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (zhuyu), *Cinnamomi Cortex* (gui), *Aconiti Radix* (wutou), *Aconiti Radix Lateralis Praeparata* (fuzi), *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (jiao), *Ginseng Radix* (renshen), *Asari Radix et Rhizoma* (xixin), *Gleditsiae Fructus* (zaojia), and *Angelicae Sinensis Radix* (danggui), adjusting quantity as needed. Pound, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten to twenty pills, three times daily. For cold-induced diarrhea, add *Halloysitum Rubrum* (chishizhi) and *Fossilia Ossis Mastodi* (longgu) for immediate relief.

*Lusuxing Wan* treats severe cold accumulations. Take three *liang* each of *Alumen* (fanshi), *Zingiberis Rhizoma* (ganjiang), *Cinnamomi Cortex* (gui), *Platycodonis Radix* (jiegeng), roasted *Aconiti Radix Lateralis Praeparata* (fuzi), and *Gleditsiae Fructus* (zaojia). Pound, sift, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with honey. Take ten pills with wine, increasing to fifteen pills.

Supplementary formulas.

chunks.original_text: 《外台秘要》：疗癖方。 大黄十两，杵，筛，醋三升，和匀，白蜜两匙，煎堪丸，如梧桐子大，一服三十丸，生姜汤吞下，以利为度，小者减之。 《圣惠方》：治伏梁气在心下，结聚不散。 用桃奴二两，为末，空心温酒调二钱匕。 《简要济众》：治久积冷不下食，呕吐不止，冷在胃中。 半夏五两，洗过，为末，每服二钱，白面一两，以水和搜，切作棋子，水煮面熟为度，用生姜、醋调和服之。 治胸膈上痰瘾诸方第二十八 治卒头痛如破，非中冷，又非中风方。 釜月下墨四分，附子三分，桂一分，捣筛，以冷水服方寸匕，当吐。 一方无桂。 又方，苦参、桂、半夏等分，捣下筛，苦酒和以涂，痛则差。 又方，乌梅三十枚，盥三指撮，酒三升，煮取一升，去滓，顿服，当吐，愈。 此本在杂治中，其病是胸中膈上，痰厥气上冲所致，名为厥，头痛，吐之即差。 但单煮米作浓饮二三升许，适冷暖，饮尽二三升，须臾适吐，适吐毕又饮，如此数过，剧者，须臾吐胆乃止，不损人而即差。 治胸中多痰，头痛不欲食及饮酒，则瘀阻痰方。 常山二两，甘草一两，松萝一两，瓜蒂三七枚，酒水各一升半，煮取升半，初服七合，取吐，吐不尽，余更分二服，后可服半夏汤。 《胡洽》名粉隔汤：矾石一两，水二升，煮取一升，内蜜半合，顿服，须臾未吐，饮少热汤。 又方，杜蘅三两，松萝三两，瓜蒂三十枚，酒一升二合，渍再宿，去滓，温服五合。 一服不吐，晚更一服。 又方，瓜蒂一两，赤小豆四两，捣末，温汤三合和服，便安卧，欲擿之，不吐，更服之。 又方，先作一升汤，投水一升，名为生熟汤，及食三合盐，以此汤送之，须臾欲吐，便摘出，未尽，更服二合，饮汤二升后，亦可更服汤，不复也。 又方，常山四两，甘草半两，水七升，煮取三升，内半升蜜，服一升，不吐更服，无蜜亦可。 方中能月服一种，则无痰水之患。 又有旋覆五饮，在诸大方中。 若胸中痞寒#9短气腷者。 腷，敷逼切。 甘草二两，茯苓三两，杏人五十枚，碎之，水一斗三升，煮取六升，分为五服。 又方，桂四两，术、甘草二两，附子炮，水六升，煮取三升，分为三服。 膈中有结积，觉骇骇不去者。 藜芦一两，炙，末之，巴豆半两，去皮心熬之，先捣巴豆如泥，入藜芦末，又捣万杵，蜜丸如麻子大，服一丸至二三丸。 膈中之病，名曰膏肓，汤丸径过，针灸不及，所以作丸含之，令气势得相熏染，有五膈丸方。 麦门冬十分，去心，甘草十分，炙，椒、远志、附子炮、乾姜、人参、桂、细辛各六分，捣筛，以上好蜜丸，如弹丸，以一丸含稍稍咽其汁，日三丸，服之，主短气，心胸满，心下坚，冷气也。 此疾有十许方，率皆相类。 此丸最胜，用药虽多，不合五膈之名，谓忧膈、气膈、恚膈、寒膈，其病各有诊别，在大方中又有七气方，大约与此大同小别耳。 附方 《圣惠方》：治痰厥头痛。 以乌梅十个，取肉，盐二钱，酒一中盏，合煎至七分，去滓，非时温服，吐即佳。 又方，治冷痰饮恶心。 用荜拨一两，捣为末，於食前用清粥饮调半钱服。 又方，治痰壅呕逆，心胸满闷不下食。 用厚朴一两，涂生姜汁，炙令黄，为末，非时粥饮调下二钱匕。

From *Waatai Miyao*: Formula for Masses (Pĭ).
Ten *liang* of *Rhei Radix et Rhizoma* (dahuang), pound, sift, mix evenly with three *sheng* of vinegar, and two spoonfuls of white honey. Simmer until pliable for pill-making, forming pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take thirty pills with fresh ginger decoction, adjusting to induce purgation; reduce dosage for milder cases.

From *Shenghui Fang*: Formula for *Fu Liang* Qi Lodged Beneath the Heart, Congealing and Unresolved.
Use two *liang* of *Persicae Fructus Immaturus* (taonu), ground to powder. Take two *qianbi* on an empty stomach, mixed with warm wine.

From *Jianyao Jizhong*: Formula for Long-standing Cold Accumulation with Inability to Eat, Persistent Vomiting, and Cold in the Stomach.
Five *liang* of *Pinelliae Rhizoma* (banxia), washed, ground to powder. For each dose, take two *qian* of powder with one *liang* of white flour, kneaded with water and cut into dice-shaped pieces. Boil in water until the flour is cooked, then consume with fresh ginger and vinegar.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight: Formulas for Phlegm-Rheum and Obstructions in the Chest and Diaphragm**

Formula for Sudden Splitting Headache, Neither from Cold Strike nor Wind Strike.
Four *fen* of *Fu Yue Xia Mo* (soot from beneath a cauldron), three *fen* of *Aconiti Radix Lateralis* (fuzi), and one *fen* of *Cinnamomi Cortex* (gui). Pound, sift, and take one *fangcunbi* with cold water to induce vomiting.
An alternate formula omits *gui*.
Another formula: equal parts *Sophorae Flavescentis Radix* (kushen), *gui*, and *banxia*. Pound, sift, mix with bitter wine, and apply topically; pain will cease.
Another formula: thirty *Mume Fructus* (wumei), a three-finger pinch of salt, and three *sheng* of wine. Boil to reduce to one *sheng*, strain, and consume in one draught to induce vomiting; this cures the condition. Originally listed among miscellaneous treatments, this ailment arises from phlegm reversal and qi surging upward in the chest and diaphragm, termed "reversal headache." Vomiting provides immediate relief.
Alternatively, cook rice into a thick gruel of two to three *sheng*, adjust to lukewarm temperature, and drink entirely. After a short while, induce vomiting; once vomiting ceases, drink again. Repeat several times. In severe cases, continue until bile is vomited. This method is harmless and immediately effective.

Formula for Copious Phlegm in the Chest, Headache with Loss of Appetite, and Stagnant Phlegm upon Drinking Alcohol.
Two *liang* of *Dichroae Radix* (changshan), one *liang* of *Glycyrrhizae Radix* (gancao), one *liang* of *Usneae Herba* (songluo), and twenty-one *Trichosanthis Fructus* (guadi). Boil in one and a half *sheng* each of wine and water to reduce to one and a half *sheng*. Initially take seven *ge*; induce vomiting. If vomiting is incomplete, divide the remainder into two doses. Later, take *Pinelliae Decoction* (Banxia Tang).

From *Hu Qia*: Named *Fen Ge Tang* (Powder-Barrier Decoction).
One *liang* of *Alumen* (fanshi) and two *sheng* of water, boiled to reduce to one *sheng*. Add half a *ge* of honey and consume in one draught. If vomiting does not occur shortly after, drink a small amount of hot water.

Another formula: three *liang* each of *Asari Herba* (duheng) and *songluo*, and thirty *guadi*. Steep in one *sheng* and two *ge* of wine for two nights, strain, and take five *ge* warm. If vomiting does not occur after the first dose, take another in the evening.

Another formula: one *liang* of *guadi* and four *liang* of *Phaseoli Semen* (chixiaodou), ground to powder. Mix with three *ge* of warm water and consume, then lie down quietly. If vomiting is desired but does not occur, take another dose.

Another formula: first prepare one *sheng* of boiling water, then add one *sheng* of cold water, naming it "raw-cooked water." Consume three *ge* of salt, followed by this water. After a short while, vomiting will commence; manually induce it. If incomplete, take another two *ge* of salt and two *sheng* of water afterward. Alternatively, take more water; vomiting will not recur.

Another formula: four *liang* of *changshan* and half a *liang* of *gancao*. Boil in seven *sheng* of water to reduce to three *sheng*, then add half a *sheng* of honey. Take one *sheng*; if vomiting does not occur, take another dose. Honey may be omitted.
Consuming one of these formulas monthly prevents phlegm-fluid afflictions.
There is also *Xuanfu Wuyin* (Five Drinks with *Inulae Flos*), found in the major formulas.

For Chest Obstruction with Cold, Shortness of Breath, and *Bi* (stifling sensation).
*Bi* is pronounced *fubi*.
Two *liang* of *gancao*, three *liang* of *Poria* (fuling), and fifty crushed *Armeniacae Semen* (xingren). Boil in one *dou* and three *sheng* of water to reduce to six *sheng*, divided into five doses.

Another formula: four *liang* of *gui*, two *liang* each of *Atractylodis Macrocephalae Rhizoma* (bai zhu) and *gancao*, and roasted *fuzi*. Boil in six *sheng* of water to reduce to three *sheng*, divided into three doses.

For Concretions in the Diaphragm, Perceived as Persistent and Unyielding.
One *liang* of *Veratri Nigri Radix et Rhizoma* (lilu), roasted and ground to powder, and half a *liang* of *Crotonis Fructus* (badou), husked and stir-fried. First pound *badou* into a paste, then add *lilu* powder and pound ten thousand times. Form into honey pills the size of sesame seeds. Take one to two or three pills.
The disease of the diaphragm is termed *gaohuang* (vital region). Decoctions and pills pass through directly, while acupuncture and moxibustion cannot reach it. Thus, pills are made for oral retention, allowing the qi and efficacy to permeate and fumigate. There is a *Wuge Wan* (Five Diaphragm Pills) formula:
Ten parts of *Ophiopogonis Radix* (maidong), deseeded, ten parts of roasted *gancao*, six parts each of *Zanthoxyli Pericarpium* (jiaomu), *Polygalae Radix* (yuanzhi), roasted *fuzi*, *Zingiberis Rhizoma* (ganjiang), *Ginseng Radix* (renshen), *gui*, and *Asari Radix et Rhizoma* (xixin). Pound, sift, and form into pills the size of a bullet with high-quality honey. Retain one pill in the mouth, gradually swallowing its juice, three pills daily. This governs shortness of breath, chest fullness, hardness beneath the heart, and cold qi.
There are over ten formulas for this condition, most being similar. This pill is the most effective. Though its ingredients are numerous, it does not align with the names of the five diaphragms—*youge* (worry diaphragm), *qige* (qi diaphragm), *huige* (anger diaphragm), and *hange* (cold diaphragm)—each with distinct diagnostic signs. In the major formulas, there is also *Qiqi Fang* (Seven Qi Formula), largely similar with minor differences.

**Supplementary Formulas**

From *Shenghui Fang*: Formula for Phlegm Reversal Headache.
Take the flesh of ten *wumei*, two *qian* of salt, and one *zhongzhan* of wine. Simmer to reduce to seven *fen*, strain, and take warm at any time; vomiting is beneficial.

Another formula: Formula for Cold Phlegm-Rheum with Nausea.
One *liang* of *Piperis Longi Fructus* (bibo), ground to powder. Take half a *qian* before meals, mixed with clear rice gruel.

Another formula: Formula for Phlegm Congestion with Retching, Chest Fullness, and Inability to Eat.
One *liang* of *Magnoliae Officinalis Cortex* (houpo), coated with fresh ginger juice and roasted until yellow, then ground to powder. Take two *qianbi* at any time, mixed with rice gruel.

chunks.original_text: 《千金翼》论曰：治痰饮吐水，无时节者，其源以冷饮过度，遂令脾胃气羸，不能消於饮食，饮食入胃，则皆变成冷水，反吐不停者。 赤石脂散主之。 赤石脂一斤，捣筛，服方寸匕，酒饮自任，稍稍加至三匕，服尽一斤，则终身不吐淡水，又不下痢，补五藏，令人肥健。 有人痰饮服诸药不效，用此方遂愈。 《御药院方》：真宗赐高祖相国，去痰清目，进饮食，生犀丸。 川芎十两，紧小者，粟米坩浸，三日换，切片子，日乾为末，作两料，每料入麝、脑各一分，生犀半两，重汤煮，蜜杵为丸，小弹子大，茶酒嚼下一丸。 痰加朱砂半两； 膈壅加牛黄一分、水飞铁粉一分； 头目昏眩加细辛一分； 口眼喎斜，炮天南星一分。 又方，治膈壅风痰。 半夏不计多少，酸浆浸一宿，温汤洗五七遍，去恶气，日中晒乾，捣为末，浆水搜饼子，日中乾之，再为末，每五两，入生脑子一钱，研匀，以浆水浓脚，丸鸡头大#10，纱袋贮，通风处阴乾，每一丸，好茶或薄荷汤下。 王氏《博济》：治三焦气不顺，胸膈壅塞，头昏目眩，涕唾痰涎，精神不爽。 利膈丸：牵牛子四两，半生半熟，不蚛皂荚涂酥二两，为末，生姜自然汁煮，糊丸如桐子大，每服二十丸，荆芥汤下。 《经验后方》：治头风化痰。 川芎不计分两，用净水洗浸，薄切片子，日乾或焙，杵为末，炼蜜为丸，如小弹子大，不拘时，茶酒嚼下。 又方，治风痰。 郁金一分，藜芦十分，各为末，和令匀，每服一字，用温浆水一盏，先以少浆水调下#11，余者水漱口，都服便以食压之。 《外台秘要》：治一切风痰，风霍乱，食不消，大便涩。 诃梨勒三枚，捣取末，和酒顿服三五度，良。 《胜金方》：治风痰。 白僵蚕七个，直者，细研，以姜汁一荼脚，温水调灌之。 又方，治风痰。 以萝卜子为末，温水调一匙头，良久吐出涎沫。 如是瘫缓风，以此吐后，用紧疏药服，疏后服和气散，差。 《斗门方》：治胸膈壅滞，去痰开胃。 用半夏净洗，焙乾，捣罗为末，以生姜自然汁和为饼子，用湿纸裹，於慢火中煨令香，熟水两盏，用饼子一块如弹丸大，入盐半钱，煎取一盏，温服，能去胸膈壅逆，大压痰毒，及治酒食所伤，其功极验。 治卒患胸痹痛方第二十九 胸痹之病，令人心中坚痞忽痛，肌中苦痹，绞急如刺，不得俛#12仰，其胸前皮皆痛，不得手犯，胸满短气，咳嗽引痛，烦闷自汗出，或彻引背膂，不即治之，数日害人。 治之方： 用雄黄、巴豆，光#13捣雄黄，细筛，内巴豆，务熟捣，相入丸如小豆大，服一丸，不效，稍益之。 又方，取枳实捣，宜服方寸匕，日三夜一服。 又方，捣栝楼实大者一枚，切，薤白半升，以白酒七升，煮取二升，分再服，亦可加半夏四两，汤洗去滑，则用之。 又方，橘皮半斤，枳实四枚，生姜半斤，水四升，煮取二升，分再服。 又方，枳实、桂等分，捣末，橘皮汤下方寸匕，日三服。 仲景方，神效。 又方，桂、乌喙、乾姜各一分，人参、细辛、茱萸各二分，贝母二分，合捣，蜜和丸，如小豆大，一服三丸，日三服之。 若已差复发者。 下韭根五斤，捣绞取汁，饮之愈。 附方 杜壬治胸膈痛彻背心，腹痞满气不得通，及治疾嗽。
